title.rendered: Canvas Collective: An Immersive Glamping Experience (with Fine-Dining)

content.rendered:
You’ve heard of glamping, right? What about haute camping? Newly launched Canvas Collective Africa is taking it up a (tent) peg or two with ultra-luxe tents and hyper-local fine dining in some of the Western Cape’s most beautiful wilderness locations.

Migrating through the year from one exquisite location to the next, Canvas Collective Africa keeps its footprint feather-light. The camp’s maiden site is near Bot River in the Overberg, an unspoilt tranche of farmland with mountain views. From July to September, the camp transfers to the Biedouw Valley in the Cederberg, in time for the transition from winter to spring-flower season. Then October to December sees summer in the Witzenberg region near Tulbagh, with views of lush vines and majestic mountains.

Tailormade tents

Founded by Dez Lundy and Samara Stern, who have combined their 20 years of experience (in luxury tented camps, event management and catering), Canvas Collective’s bespoke tents are the type of luxury escape you can sink right into, with butler service and a mobile fine-dining restaurant adding an extra layer of luxury.

Each of the 10 tents is equipped with a king-sized bed with gorgeous linen and blankets, hand-crafted furniture, a minibar and Nespresso machine, freestanding lamps, soft rugs underfoot, and luxurious bathrooms – with hot and cold running water, rain showers and flushing loos. Cushioned loungers and a fancy fireball fireplace outside each tent frame your mountain views in perfect privacy.

The Field Kitchen

Designed in glass, steel and canvas, with simply styled décor and maximum views, The Field Kitchen serves up gastronomic delights from foraged and hyper-local ingredients. Expect fine cuisine prepared with fire and smoke that draws inspiration from local fynbos and the distinctive biome of each location.


Anton Crone

Think aromatic rose pelargonium, broom buchu, waterberries and wild garlic, matched with wines from nearby estates. Breakfast in bed, country picnics, high tea in the veld, gourmet dinners, and midnight snacks under the stars are on the all-inclusive menu.

Welcome to the Biedouw Valley

From 7 July to 30 September 2022, Canvas Collective’s spring camp moves to one of the most magical (and remote) settings in the Cape. Here, in the heart of the Cederberg, glampers will not only be treated to a dazzling display of spring wildflowers; but also striking landscapes and rock formations for which the area is known.

The luxury tents will be set up on the banks of a spring-fed dam on Enjo Nature Farm before floral season – which means that some lucky campers will literally be sleeping amid the flowers.

By day, venture into the flower fields (armed with a picnic hamper and camera), explore hiking paths, go bouldering, watch the wild horses, and enjoy the camp’s offerings – including a hot tub, gourmet dinners paired with local wines, and nights beside the roaring fire, sipping brandy and gazing at the Milky Way (there is a telescope on hand).

The cost per tent includes all meals, high tea in the veld, midnight snacks and all beverages apart from premium brands. Each camp offers a different biome to discover and a variety of activities tailored to your interests. A minimum two-night stay affords ample opportunity to absorb the tranquillity of the setting.

Cost From R6 500 per tent per night (sleeps 2; children are welcome by arrangement)
Where to find it Enjo Nature Farm, Biedouw Valley, off the R364, near Clanwilliam
Check Availability + Book Direct

title.rendered: Happiness On The Rock: A Luxury Country Getaway in Piket-Bo-Berg

content.rendered:
The journey to Happiness on The Rock, a Cinderella-like old farmhouse in the secret valley of Piket-Bo-Berg, is a special experience. You’ll meander through the village of Piketberg (where you can stock up on necessities) before ascending the picturesque Piketberg Mountains via Versfeld Pass. The narrow road twists and turns all the way to the top of a plateau, on top of which a beautiful, relatively undiscovered part of the Western Cape is revealed. Here, the cooler climate is conducive to fruit and flower farming, with rows of orchards along the way.

It’s not hard to fathom why the owners fell in love with the area and its community, and then decided to transform the house into a magical luxury destination.

Situated next to a dirt road just off the main road, the property beckons with its charming and unpretentious exterior. At night, an old tree strung with fairy lights lights up a ginormous rock that becomes a striking sight – the inspiration behind the house’s name.

The lodgings

The delightful, warm and welcoming home is full of stylish personality – from the bright open-plan kitchen and living areas (with an enclosed fireplace that cosies up the entire space) to the library room (chock-a-block with books and games) and the elegantly designed bedrooms and bathrooms.

Tactile elements such as wicker, wood and leather combine with fine linen and cottons in gentle hues to create a sense of laidback luxury. Top-of-the-range fittings and fixtures, and luxuriously soft furnishings and bedding, complete the picture.

  • three bedrooms (king beds)
  • two bathrooms (main is en-suite)
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • pizza oven
  • indoor fireplace
  • outdoor fireplace
  • private pool
  • complimentary wi-fi

While you’re there

If you don’t feel like preparing your meals in the fully kitted-out kitchen, light a fire in the pizza oven, or built-in braai on the verandah, but first, take your pick of produce from the fruit and vegetable garden to perk up your dishes.

Visiting the monthly Farmers Market on Kruistementvlei Farm is a must. It’s a 10-minute drive from the house and you’ll be delighted by the variety of country fare on offer: traditional moerkoffie, homemade eats, farm-fresh fruit and vegetables and oodles of charming handmade knickknacks.

Feel like stretching your legs? There are numerous hiking trails among the orchards and further afield. At Groot Winterhoek you can do the Waterfall trail: beautiful scenery with pristine rock pools for cooling down.

The area is also a mountain biker’s paradise, with The U, an annual event that takes place in September. Other sporting options include the well-known paragliding launching point at Versfeld Pass on the way to Piket-Bo-Berg.

The quaint village Porterville is also worth a visit, with a golf course and a dam for fishing as well as the Houdconstant Country Market that offers tractor and pony rides for children.

Nighttime calls for wrapping up in a fluffy blanket pulled from the basket on the verandah before relaxing on a comfortable chair and marveling at the star-spangled country sky.

Distance from CT 1 hour 47 minutes
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? Yes
Wifi Yes, free
Sleeps 6
Cost From R5 500 per night (depending on season)
Where to find it The House at Piket-Bo-Berg, Piketberg, Western Cape
MAKE A RESERVATION

title.rendered: Camp Canoe: A Glamping Escape on a Franschhoek Wine Farm

content.rendered:
One of the Cape’s oldest wine estates, dating back to 1685, Boschendal flaunts spectacular surroundings: with dramatic mountain vistas wherever you find yourself on the expansive property.

It’s here, tucked among lush fynbos, olive trees and boulders on the rustic side of the Simonsberg Mountains that the recently introduced (and entirely independent) Camp Canoe glamping escape takes centre stage.

The luxury tents are far removed from the foot traffic of the nearby estate and guests are encouraged to switch off, unwind and reconnect with nature. Waking at sunrise to the sound of birdsong from the comfort of a sumptuous king-size bed, before embarking on a day of wine-tasting and epicurean experiences is a special kind of luxury.

Stay the night

The seven, sizeable tents are generously spaced apart, offering privacy and fuss-free laidback living. Each unit overlooks the sparkling dam, with lush flora encasing the exterior walls and a wood-fired hot tub elevating the experience to extraordinary.

  • 7 luxury tents, each sleeping 2 adults (children on request)
  • king-size bed
  • en suite bathroom with a shower
  • indoor seating area
  • viewing deck with outdoor seating
  • private hot tub and hammocks
  • complimentary wifi

It’s definitely an experience to add to the bucketlist!

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? Yes, on request
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 2 adults
Cost From R2 600 per unit per night (depending on season)
Where to find it Boschendal Estate, Pniel Street, Groot Drakenstein, Franschhoek
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

title.rendered: Opstal Stay: Hot Tubs with a View at these Cabins in Breedekloof

content.rendered:
Tucked between the Slanghoek and Badsberg Mountains, surrounded by endless nature, Opstal Estate is a tranquil place, where a cluster of modern mountain cabins provide cosy, stylish nests for some real R&R, no matter what time of year you visit.

Woven into the fabric and history of the Slanghoek Valley, this seventh-generation property (dating back to 1847) offers an idyllic stayover that combines magnificent scenery and true country-style hospitality.

The lodgings

The five modern, self-catering cottages are perfectly (and privately) positioned to maximise the valley and mountain views, with large picture windows and sliding doors, and unspoilt nature just footsteps away.

Inside, the contemporary open-plan architecture and quality furnishings provide a comfortable home-from-home (and it’s good to know the water in the taps comes fresh from a mountain stream). An outdoor deck with a luxurious Kol-Kol hot tub sets the scene for an unforgettable and relaxing stay.

  • The Barber and Carl Everson cottages each sleep 4
  • Lang Jan, Nellie’s Needle and Lady Ansie cottages each sleep 2
  • bathroom with shower
  • quality bed linen and towels supplied
  • fully equipped kitchen with gas hob
  • living area with a slow-combustion fireplace
  • indoor and outdoor dining tables
  • sheltered outdoor deck with a braai
  • wood-burning hot tub (plunge pool in summer)
  • outdoor shower (in the two-sleeper units)
  • complimentary firewood bundle

While you’re there

Opstal is a working wine farm, producing three ranges (Sixpence, Estate and Heritage) – find your favourite by booking a tasting, then take a few bottles back to your cottage to enjoy on your deck. Chef PJ Lombard offers a seasonal menu of country-comfort classics at the restaurant, so guests can treat themselves to breakfast (from 9am to 11am) or lunch, which includes pizzas and platters. Sunday lunch is a local highlight.

Opstal also offers an Opstal Vars (fresh box) of seasonal goodies made on the farm or sourced from the area’s small producers – items such as honey, mushrooms, free-range eggs, jams and sauces, olive oil, herbs and coffee.

The farm itself is yours to explore on foot or by bicycle, or book an adventure on the trekkertrein (“tractor train”), which winds its way through the vineyards with a stop for a picnic on the farm. During harvest time, guests are welcome to join in the farm activities.

The Breedekloof itself is one of the Cape’s hidden gems, with a wine route comprising almost more than a dozen wine estates to explore, as well as a distillery, farm stalls, restaurants and more in Rawsonville, the area’s central hub. Outdoor lovers will relish the activities in the area: mountain-biking, fly-fishing and birdwatching.

Cost From R1 750 per night (two-sleeper cottages)
From R2 300 per night (four-sleeper cottages)
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes

title.rendered: Clouds Estate: Majestic Views + Quirky Luxury on the Helshoogte Pass

content.rendered:
On the crest of the Helshoogte Pass, surrounded by the majestic Drakenstein mountains perches a five-star boutique hotel (and working farm)aptly named Clouds Estate. From here, the views across the Banhoek Valley are sublime – a perk the Dutch owners of this luxury property took full advantage of when they bought it in 2009. They overhauled and redesigned the existing hotel, installing floor-to-ceiling glass windows and sliding doors to allow the exquisite views inside.

Inside, Dutch design company Moooi has created chic and contemporary spaces, punctuated by playful details – such as a life-size black horse lamp by Front in the lounge and rhino sculptures by Phumani Paper in the dining area.

Speaking of art, the hotel has a supreme collection of South African art displayed throughout, including works by Strijdom van der Merwe, Kobus le Grange and Kurt Pio. Oh, and look out for the sculpture of a roaming pig in the garden!

The lodgings

The seven rooms all have views across the beautiful valley, while the six designer villas are set in landscaped gardens and surrounded by vineyards. The balconies are perfect for an alfresco lunch or dinner.

  • 7 bedrooms in the main hotel (2 luxury, 1 standard, 1 superior and 3 deluxe) and 6 villas (5 deluxe and 1 Cloud 9 with two en suite bedrooms)
  • Mulberry silk king-size pillows and duvets
  • Charlotte Rhys toiletries
  • heated towel rails
  • flip-flops
  • private patio or balcony
  • Nespresso machine
  • smart TV, satellite TV and Blu-Ray DVD
  • complimentary minibar stocked with Clouds’ wine, beer, soft drinks and fruit juice
  • air conditioning
  • underfloor heating

While you’re there…

Breakfast is served daily in the mountain-facing dining area. And if you don’t fancy venturing too far away from this blissful haven, order a light lunch and relax by the pool with a chilled glass of Clouds sauvignon blanc and let the surrounding mountains and vineyards do their thing.

Clouds’ convenient perch on the Helshoogte Pass (the oldest pass in the country) means you can take a short 10-minute drive into Stellenbosch for a dose of small -own culture and to explore some restaurants, bars, galleries and shops. Or, go the other way down the pass to Franschhoek (a 20-minute drive) for more shopping and eating options in this charming village.

Nature lovers will be in their element with the plethora of hiking and mountain-biking trails in the area.

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? No children under 16 (rooms)
No children under 12 (villas)
Pet friendly? No
Cost From R3 995 per room per night including breakfast
Where to find it Helshoogte Road, Stellenbosch

title.rendered: Brookdale: An Elegant Country Retreat with Unbeatable Views in Paarl

content.rendered:
In a valley encircled by the Klein Drakenstein mountains, Brookdale Estate has come to life, offering guests the proverbial slice of heaven. It’s a place to slow down and enjoy the pastoral rhythms of the seasons, big African skies, birdsong and serenity. It’s also a rare opportunity to witness the blossoming of a wine estate, and to watch the passion, work and sense of adventure this involves.

When Tim Rudd bought 67 hectares of overgrown farmland in 2015, he set about removing alien vegetation and withered vines, planting over 2 000 trees, vegetable and indigenous gardens and rows of new vines. (He kept just one block of old-growth chenin, which by happy accident turned into the estate’s first wine, released in 2019, now a certified Old Vine.)

Apart from its utterly spectacular setting (which is reason enough to visit), Brookdale is all about creature comforts and little luxuries. Husband-and-wife team Gary and Yvonne Coetzee, who have a wealth of hospitality experience (including working at Singita and for Sol Kerzner) are warm hosts (and consummate professionals), who effortlessly and elegantly create a personalised guest experience you’ll be hard-pressed to find elsewhere.

The lodgings

The Cape Dutch-style Manor House is the epitome of Winelands living. Within its whitewashed walls are two dining rooms, a private study, two lounges, a fitness room and a view-drenched kitchen, which comes with the services of a private chef (more about that later). The Manor House also has a pool house, and several courtyards and terraces from which to soak up the spectacular views.

The rooms are lofty, and elegantly dressed in a mix of contemporary and period furnishings, and a muted colour palette that does not detract from the breathtaking views of sprawling vines, flourishing orchards, undulating multi-hued hills and dramatic mountains from every single window.

The six suites can be booked individually for a romantic getaway, or the entire house can be rented for exclusive use – a popular option for families, corporates or groups of friends travelling together.

  • 5 Manor House suites and 1 Vineyard room, sleeping 2 adults each
  • en-suite (bath and shower), plus a separate cloak room on the ground level
  • roll-away beds for 2 children under 12 years sharing the suite with their parents, plus a baby’s cot
  • 3 fireplaces
  • air-conditioning
  • smart TV in all suites
  • complimentary minibar, tea and coffee
  • tea and coffee station
  • daily breakfast

Five-star dining

Meals at Brookdale are exceptional – served in a different location each day. From the beautifully conceived and executed dishes to the superb service and impeccable setting, it’s the kind of food we’d happily eat every day for the rest of our lives: healthy, flavourful, delicious, with ample variation and surprising ingredients to keep us rapt.

On our first evening, we sat on the east terrace, overlooking the vegetable garden while Gary’s kitchen assistant, Charlene, plucked spinach and a crop of other greens for our shakshuka breakfast the following morning (which we enjoyed on the sun-dappled pool terrace). We started with “tomato water and Parmesan tuile” (a heavenly gazpacho that Gary described as a “guilt-free cheese and tomato sarmie”, followed by a charred-cauliflower risotto with pine nuts and truffle salsa. Then came the crispy duck breast, with sweet potato rounds, ending with a fillet, served with pea purée, broccoli and baby hasselback potato. As for the coffee crème with vanilla ice cream – sublime.

While you’re there

The estate offers a place to unwind, relax and simply just be, taking dips in the spectacular pool or snuggling up with a good book in one of the lounges or the hammock. Pampering in-room massages can be booked and, given the location, a hosted wine tasting of the estate’s two ranges, Brookdale and Mason Road, is a must. (Also in the pipeline is a restaurant and tasting lounge – but for now, wine tasting is a unique, private experience for guests in the Manor House.)

That said, there are many reasons to explore further – from rambles in the orchards or a tractor ride and picnic in the vineyards, to watching the working farm’s activities (whether at harvest time or the magic that happens in the cellar). There are also hiking, cycling, running and horse-riding trails through fynbos and along streams.

Beyond the gates lie the wine routes of Paarl, Franschhoek, Stellenbosch and Wellington, with myriad estates, restaurants, galleries and boutiques. There are also many nature trails and activities nearby, with Paarlberg Reserve being a locals’ favourite.

The pool terrace, with its generously proportioned and fully kitted out pool house, beckons on hot, lazy summer days – and is the only place to be at day’s end, enjoying the spectacular sunset, glass of wine in hand, as night falls magically over this enchanted estate.

Distance from CT 67km (50 mins)
Child friendly? Yes, ideal for families booking exclusive-use as a private villa.
Two additional children under 12 can be accommodated sharing with their parents
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Cost per room From R6 560
Where to find it Hawequa Bos Road, Klein Drakenstein, Paarl

title.rendered: Fairview House: A Tranquil Fynbos Escape outside Plettenberg Bay

content.rendered:
Set on a 28-hectare headland at The Crags (between Plettenberg Bay and Nature’s Valley), every window at Fairview House frames endless views over fynbos-clad slopes and the Keurbooms indigenous forest to the Tsitsikamma Mountains… There is serenity and silence, time to slow down and relax into the gentle enfolding warmth of unspoilt country living.

The Cape Dutch-style homestead has been home to three generations of the Rattray family, the force behind Fugitive’s Drift, an award-winning lodge in KwaZulu-Natal. The recent renovation has upgraded Fairview House from family home to luxury boutique hotel, although that personal family touch is still evident, with Andrew and Anel Rattray as welcoming hosts.

All this peace and nature feels like it’s miles from anywhere, but it’s only a short drive from the beach and nature hotspots of Plettenberg Bay and Nature’s Valley, making the ideal base for exploration if you can tear yourself away.

The lodgings

Interior designer, Heather Hensley, took inspiration from South African artist Irma Stern in the colour palette, updating country-house style with contemporary panache. She worked with Nicky Rattray to include family furniture and pictures, so that layers of history remain to balance the new, and she selected artworks from the Everard Read Gallery to hang on the walls. Clean lines, custom-made fabrics, contemporary furnishings alongside vintage, the overall effect is comfortable and timeless, with couches you really can sink into.

The eight bedrooms and suites, two in the main house, six in the nearby Coach House, open out onto balconies or patios so it’s easy to lose yourself in those mesmerising views, which change with the light from pastel sunrise to glorious sunset.

  • 2 bedrooms in the Main House (standard room and luxury room)
  • 6 rooms in the Coach House (2 deluxe family suites and 4 luxury garden rooms: 2 king, 2 twin)
  • en-suite bathroom with a bath and shower
  • private patio or balcony
  • study nook and seating area
  • smart TV with select DStv channels
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • complimentary wifi
  • air conditioning

While you’re there

Soak up the serenity of the fynbos on walking and bicycle trails, feasting your eyes on the endless horizons of successive mountain ranges and exploring shady pine forests. Lounge by the pool in the peace of the fynbos garden, grab a book from the library and settle into a garden nook for the afternoon.

Breakfast is on the deep verandah in summer, and beside the dining room’s wood-burning stove in winter, and lazy picnics in the garden add to the feeling of country idyll. The vegetable garden supplies fresh ingredients for breakfast (as well as lunch, dinner and picnics by arrangement); the rest is sourced from local independent producers.

The property is only a 10-minute drive to Plettenberg Bay in one direction and 15 minutes to Nature’s Valley in the other, so you’re perfectly placed to dip into all the attractions along this stretch of the Garden Route, from beach bliss and wine-tasting, to polo, golf, whale-watching and nature hikes, retreating to the tranquil embrace of this beautiful hideaway to recharge in between.

Distance from CT 6 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Cost From R3 000 per room per night (depending on season and room type), includes breakfast
Where to find it Fairview Farm, N2, The Crags, Western Cape

title.rendered: Majeka House & Spa: An Arty Bolthole in the Stellenbosch Winelands

content.rendered:
Tucked below the Blaauwklippen Mountains, surrounded by vineyards and scenic forests, the suburb of Paradyskloof is, as its name suggests, a slice of paradise. It is here, on the edge of a quiet residential street, a short two-minute drive from Stellenbosch’s bustling town centre, that Majeka House & Spa takes centre stage. A destination in its own right – with an acclaimed restaurant, heavenly spa and five-star lodgings – it offers a tranquil reprieve from city life.

Its artfully quirky interior design earned the hotel a Condé Nast Award for Best Design Hotel in Africa & the Middle East in 2016. And its on-site restaurant, Majeka Kitchen, has also garnered numerous foodie accolades since it opened in 2008.

Kids stay free special

From now until 30 November 2021, this design destination is running an unbeatable special for South African residents where kids stay for free when sharing with adults (Ts+Cs apply)!

Cost From R1 505 per adult sharing per night (depending on room type)
The details One child and one infant (15 years and under) stays free when sharing a room with two paying adults (single rates also available). Complimentary breakfast is included.
Valid until 30 November 2021 (subject to availability)

The lodgings

  • 21 individually decorated rooms (namely Premiere Collection Rooms, Garden Alternative Rooms, Mountain View Rooms and Poolside Rooms)
  • en suite bathroom with a bath and/or shower
  • flat-screen TV with Netflix and DStv
  • chaise longue and desk
  • complimentary mini bar
  • Lavazza coffee machine
  • private terrace or balcony
  • Poolside and Garden Alternative Rooms share a semi-private pool, while the Mountain View Rooms have views of the herb garden, fish pond and surrounding mountains
  • air conditioning
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

A large indoor heated pool – with adjoining Jacuzzi – overlooks a beautifully manicured garden and leads to an intimate sauna and steam room and the heavenly Majeka Spa.

Apart from offering all the classic treatments (facials, massages, waxes, manicures and pedicures), wraps, scrubs and spa packages can be booked.

Looking for a pre-dinner aperitif? The beautifully designed M Lounge offers a range of cocktails and top South African wines. Majeka House & Spa is also a stones throw away from some of the best restaurants and wine estates in Stellenbosch for those looking to get out and explore the surrounds.

Being in the heart of wine-farm country, there is no shortage of things to do in the area – from hiking and mountain-biking to wine-tasting, picnics and high teas.

Distance from CT 45 minutes
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Cost From R1 630 per adult sharing per night (depending on room type); kids stay for free when sharing with adults (Ts+Cs apply)
Where to find it 26-32 Houtkapper Street, Paradyskloof, Stellenbosch, Western Cape

title.rendered: Cartel House Hotel: New York-Style Suites on Loop Street

content.rendered:
Boasting 360-degree views of Table Mountain, Signal Hill and the city skyline, Cartel House Hotel is the epitome of a central stay. In addition to six kitted-out suites (ideal for short or long stays), a wonderful brunch and breakfast spot, on-site gym and a bevvy of excitement on your doorstep, the hotel is perfectly suited for those looking for a home-from-home experience.

Whether you’re in town for business or pleasure, or you need a place to stay while your transfer or lease agreement is being approved, or you’re seeking a comfortable spot for your out-of-town guests to stay, Cartel House Hotel ticks all those boxes.

The lodgings

Each of the six suites are individually dressed, with view-drenched terraces, wall-to-ceiling windows and four-poster beds creating the ideal nesting space for innercity living. And although it’s self-catering, the hotel offers breakfast each morning (at an additional cost), and an on-site restaurant for brunch and lunch.

  • 6 rooms with a queen-size bed (Terrace Room, Skyline Room, Poster Room, Cityscape Room, Business Suite and The Apartment)
  • en-suite bathroom with a walk-in shower and free-standing bathtub (in four of the six rooms)
  • work desk
  • large smart TV
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • digital concierge in each room
  • minibar
  • freshly baked biscuits on arrival
  • dining table, spacious lounge and kitchenette in The Apartment
  • air conditioning
  • complimentary wifi
  • laundry and housekeeping services

While you’re there

On the ground floor, you’ll find Brunch Café that serves breakfast, brunch, buffet-style hot meals and lunch seven days a week. There is also a clubhouse and rooftop pool (currently closed for renovations), as well as an on-site gym and secure valet parking.

You’ll also have access to all of the Cartel Club members’ lounges and bars, coworking spaces throughout the city and, of course, the slew of restaurants, cafés, bars and shops on your doorstep.

Win when you book a room

Book a two-night stay via the link below (using the code #CAPETOWNSUMMER) before 30 November 2021 and stand the chance to win the following prizes worth more than R100 000.

The prizes

  • R50 000 cash prize
  • hopper tour for two with NAC Helicopters Cape Town
  • overnight stay for two at Pearl Valley Hotel (includes breakfast)
  • one-day tour with the Surfing Sommelier
  • SUP with penguins or a surfing lesson, followed by an afternoon of wine-tasting in the Constantia Valley
  • two-night stay for two at The Last Word Constantia
  • Anthonij Rupert wine-tasting, a visit to the Franschhoek Motor Museum and a high tea experience for 4
  • a case of L’Ormarins Cap Classique Wines
  • gin-crafting experience at the Inverroche Gin Academy at Misfits for 12 guests
  • A four-ball session on the Golf Simulator at Pebble Beach

Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? Yes
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 2 per room
Cost From R1 274 per room per night (depending on season and room type)
Where to find it 8th Floor, Cartel House,113 Loop Street, Cape Town City Centre
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

title.rendered: Maison Cabrière: Stylish Suites in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
When Dutch owners Eveline and Alexander de Vries-Spruijt decided to escape their fast-paced life in Amsterdam, they figured Franschhoek would be the perfect place to wind down. So, they created Maison Cabrière, a beautiful property that they renovated into an intimate boutique hotel with six stylish suites.

The couple wanted to create a space that “combined the best elements of a hotel stay and an Airbnb rental”. In other words, a place that’s utterly comfortable and considered, and also offers all you need to make it your own while you’re there.

Stylish decor aside, the property has loads going for it, not least its central location just a three-minute walk from Franschhoek’s main drag, and its tranquil gardenside setting ensuring privacy and discretion.

The lodgings

A small wooden gate from the private parking opens onto a charming pathway lined with lavender and rosemary bushes that, in turn, leads into a beautifully manicured garden with suites overlooking it.

Of the six boutique suites, three are located in the main house, and three are in an adjacent building. Some have a private terrace overlooking the garden, while others have their own capacious balconies offering views of the mountain. All are imbued with an unmistakable modern-Scandi aesthetic, featuring blonde-wood finishes, unique handmade furniture and tasteful pops of colour.

  • 3 suites in the main house
  • 3 suites in the adjacent house (one with its own kitchenette)
  • king-size bed
  • en-suite bathroom with a walk-in shower, double vanities and free-standing bath
  • private garden terrace or mountain-facing balcony
  • fireplace in most suites
  • Nespresso machine (with pods) and tea-making facilities
  • Bose Soundlink mini speaker
  • air conditioning and underfloor heating
  • complimentary wifi
  • TV with select DStv channels/ Netflix
  • communal lounge and honesty bar
  • spacious outdoor area with a wooden deck, pool and sun loungers
  • undercover gazebo with cushioned couches

While you’re there

The spacious outdoor area boasts a wooden deck, with a sizable pool and an array of sun loungers and towels that beckon on sunny afternoons. There’s also an undercover gazebo with luxurious cushioned couches – the perfect spot to curl up with a book and a chilled glass of wine before heading out to lunch.

Should you tire of relaxing, a fleet of vintage-style bikes is available for exploring the area. Else, just continue languishing on one of the couches in the lounge, with a pile of magazines and a snack.

Hospitable hosts, a central location, and a garden that will melt away your worries, Maison Cabrière is one of those ineluctable Franschhoek gems.

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? No
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 2 per suite
Cost From R3 000 – R5 000 per night (depending on season and suite type)
Where to find it 49 – 51 Cabriere Street, Franschhoek

title.rendered: Old Foundry Hotel by Ideas Cartel: An Innercity Bolthole

content.rendered:
One look at the slick, up-to-the-minute interiors and carefully-thought-out array of facilities at this hot innercity hotel, it’s hard to believe it was once a commercial foundry (the first ever) dating back to 1876.

An eclectic mix of old-world sophistication and modern style, Old Foundry Hotel (the flagship spot of Ideas Cartel) is home to 24 beautifully dressed rooms, as well as a gym, restaurant, co-working spaces and even a Golf Simulator! Located in the heart of De Waterkant, it’s central location is hard to beat.

The lodgings

Hand-picked antique furniture, decorative tiling and local artworks give the rooms a designer edge, with kitchenettes enabling guests to enjoy light meals in their rooms (Master Suites have fully equipped kitchens).

  • 24 rooms divided into Bijou Rooms, Studio Rooms and Master Suites
  • king-size bed

title.rendered: The Majestic: An Artful Seaside Sojourn on the Kalk Bay Strip

content.rendered:
Kalk Bay, on Cape Town’s False Bay coast, is the little seaside village that has it all – oozing the nostalgic charm of past grandeur while buzzing with modern quirkiness and sophistication. There’s a little fishing harbour where, yes, the fishing boats still anchor; there’s a main road lined with shops, eateries and that essential ice-cream parlour; and a labyrinth of cobbled lanes hiding even more finds. And then there’s the ocean, just metres away, blue and beautiful and always present in all its moods.

Kalk Bay is as popular now as it was 100 years ago, when it was the de rigueur seaside destination – the grand mansions that remain attest to that. The Majestic Hotel & Apartments is one of those – formerly a hotel built in 1916, it was rescued from ruin in 2006 and converted, along with a few other buildings, into an eye-catching pink complex in the very hub of Kalk Bay.

The lodgings

This spacious, first-floor apartment truly conjures up Kalk Bay’s glory days, with its Art Deco features and high ceilings, elegant antiques and an art collection of note (inherited from the owner’s parents). There are several spots to eat and drink and relax, indoors and out – but the most popular is likely to be the front terrace, with its comfy sofas, daybeds and 10-seater table (plus large shutter windows for those bad-weather days).

Despite the great choice of eateries in the area, you will not be able to resist the French-style kitchen – fitted with everything you might need, right down to a wine cooler, and equipped with the very best cookware and tableware (Le Creuset, Villeroy & Boch, Spode, and so on).

Large windows throughout the apartment let in the light, the sound of the sea and those magnificent views – all the way to the mountains on the other side of the bay, with the most magical sunrises (if you can drag yourself out of the comfy bed that early).

  • three en-suite bedrooms (one with a king-size bed, and two with two single beds)
  • bathrooms with shower and/or bath
  • fully equipped kitchen, with dishwasher and washing machine
  • open-plan living room with a flatscreen TV and DStv
  • 2 indoor fireplaces
  • 10-seater dining table inside and another 10-seater table outside
  • front terrace with floor-to-ceiling foldaway windows
  • second spacious outdoor patio facing the mountain
  • access to communal pool, gym, spa and secure garage/parking
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

There are tidal pools to discover (Dalebrook and Woolley’s being the closest), while Fish Hoek has a great swimming beach and Muizenberg is surf central.

Olympia Bakery is right next door, Cape to Cuba’s beach bar is across the road, and it’s a quick walk to the harbour for fish-and-chips takeaways – a must-do. Or book at one of the harbour restaurants for the best sea-view dining in town. Down the road are many more coffee shops, cafés, restaurants, galleries and antique stores. And there’s high tea at Casa Labia, another one of the grand old mansions.

Distance from CT 30 minutes
Child friendly? Yes, 12 years and older
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 6
Cost From R5 760 per night (October)
From R6 120 per night (November)
From R7 200 per night (December)
Where to find it 124 Main Road, Kalk Bay, Cape Town

title.rendered: The Boat House: A Slick Beach Pad on the West Coast

content.rendered:
Weskus is die Beskus, so the saying goes. And if you’re fortunate enough to have spent time in one of the small towns along this windswept coast, you’ll understand its appeal.

One such spot is Yzerfontein, a once-tiny fishing village with a cluster of weatherbeaten holiday homes and a reliable surf break. Over the years, Yzers (as it’s affectionately known) has grown in size, while still retaining its dorp-like charm. And its sunsets are the kind that creep into your soul.

Design rules

On a stretch of road, just a few moments from the ocean is a brand-new holiday home kitted out with everything you need for a comfortable coastal escape.

Completed in July 2021, this Scandi-esque beach babe – once a somewhat ramshackle boathouse – might be compact, but what it lacks in size, it certainly makes up for in design might.

Designed by local architect Lawden Holmes (FWJK) and friend Rhett Williams-Jones, the insides are clad in suitably stylish blonde wood, and filled with carefully chosen local pieces, gleaming SMEG appliances and beautiful terrazzo floors. Together, these details are a distinct showcase of sharp style and modern comfort – there’s even a toasty fireplace for post-beach afternoons under a blanket with a book.

The lodgings

The Boat House sleeps four comfortably in two queen-size bedrooms, with an open-plan kitchen and dining area setting the scene for a convivial coastal escape.

  • 2 bedrooms with queen-size beds
  • shared bathroom with a walk-in rain shower
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • open-plan lounge and dining area
  • indoor wood-burning fireplace
  • rooftop deck with a Kolkol wood-fired hot tub
  • desk space
  • smart TV with Netflix and DStv
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

Yzerfontein is a charming village whose down-to-earth vibe is beguiling – just don’t drop in on one of the locals’ waves. There are a number of quaint eateries but nothing beats sundowner fish and chips on the rocks! And don’t forget to enquire about Blue and Sanchéz, the resident Jeep and Vespa, available for rent to get around Yzers at your leisure.

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? Yes
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 4
Cost From R2 929 per night for the house (depending on season)
Where to find it Yzerfontein, Western Cape

title.rendered: Rozendal Guest Farm: A Restful Retreat in the Stellenbosch Countryside

content.rendered:
When Johannesburg-based restaurateurs Lynette and Kurt Ammamm moved to the Cape in the early 80s with the dream of escaping the big smoke for a restful farm life, they found their “haven” on Earth at Rozendal. Now run by their children, Nathalie (the farm’s vinaigrier) and Alex (an architect by trade), Rozendal started off as a wine farm, but serendipitously pivoted into a vinegar-making operation when a visitor to the farm helped Kurt transform a flawed vintage into vinegar.

In addition to the vinegar cellar (that doubles as a pop-up restaurant on weekends), the storybook farm is home to a beautiful country cottage, a large swimming pool and a lush, treed meadow where two alpacas, two cows, Truffles (a pig with a very sophisticated palate), a horse named Shilwan and Polly Rococo the rooster reside.

The lodgings

Usually home to various accommodation options, (which are now being used as long-term rentals due to Covid), Rozendal has just one unit available for rent: the beautiful (and wonderfully private) Plumbago Country Cottage, designed and decorated by Alex whose considered approach to space and interiors is utterly inspiring.

A floor-to-ceiling kitchen window frames the meadow outside, while the spacious lounge opens onto a verandah with a braai overlooking the farm fields, and the Botmaskop and Simonsberg Mountains beyond.

Cottage features

  • 2 bedrooms (one with a queen-size bed and one with a double bed)
  • shared bathroom with a double shower and bath
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • open-plan lounge and dining area
  • indoor fireplace
  • large outdoor deck with a shaded dining area and braai
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

The charming farm setting is the perfect place for scenic strolls, lazing around the sparkling swimming pool, doing a hike or mountain-bike ride in the nearby Jonkershoek reserve, or simply pottering around the patio, waiting for a visit from your four-legged neighbours.

Those seeking a break from cooking will be delighted to know about the weekend pop-up dinners (by Jess and Luke) that take place inside the cellar and spill onto a tree-shaded patio, while the unique vinegar-tasting tour is a wonderful way to experience the fruits of the land.

There is also ample opportunity to birdwatch, as well as a farm shop stocked with vinegar- and olive-related products, freshly baked goods and preserves.

Rozendal is the sort of place that’s ideal for a weekend getaway or an extended midweek break. When it was time to leave, we headed down the dusty farm road for the last time, with contented smiles on our faces that stayed with us well into our drive back to Cape Town.

Distance from CT 45 minutes
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 4
Cost From R2 300 per night for 4 people (depending on season)
Where to find it Omega Road, Rozendal, Stellenbosch, Western Cape

title.rendered: Kinghorns Gardens: A Luxury Retreat in Noordhoek

content.rendered:
Characterised by a smattering of smallholdings, horse paddocks and wide, sandy beaches, the coastal town of Noordhoek never fails to charm visitors with its easy-breezy atmosphere, magnificent outlooks and an infectious community-driven village centre that brims with restaurants, art galleries and shops.

One place to relax and soak up the scene is Kinghorns Gardens – a beautiful home on a private tract of land with an extraordinary garden. Conceived, designed and decorated by owner Andreas Kinghorn, an aesthete to the nth degree, the boutique self-catering villa has only two bedrooms and is surrounded by a hectare of landscaped greenery brimming with water features, a Koi fish dam, sculptures and other delightful discoveries.

The lodgings

A considered indoor-outdoor flow, with natural stone and hardwood elements throughout, lends itself to the tranquil surrounds, where the sounds of birdsong and rustling leaves set the scene for a soporific stay. Modern amenities and carefully considered furnishings are around every corner, ensuring a sumptuous schlep-free stay.

  • 2 spacious bedrooms with four-poster king-size beds
  • en-suite bathrooms with a freestanding bath and walk-in shower
  • desk, TV and wood-burning fireplace in each bedroom
  • private patio off of each bedroom
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • open-plan lounge and 10-seater oak dining table
  • central wood-burning fireplace
  • wine and spirits bar
  • stocked library
  • TV with DStv, Apple TV, Bluray/DVD player and Netflix
  • state of the art Pioneer Vinyl sound system
  • outdoor deck with a swimming pool and sun loungers
  • outdoor shaded dining area with a braai
  • separate 25 sqm sunset deck
  • 5 outdoor seating areas throughout the garden
  • two outdoor showers
  • sauna deck with a large waterfall shower

While you’re there

The sundeck overlooks a fynbos-covered gardenscape and sparkling dam with beautiful Koi fish, with sea views in the distance completing the picture for a deep relaxation sojourn. In addition to a botanical plot and an intimate nature reserve, there’s a small herb and vegetable garden, where guests (and local community members) are invited to pick a selection of homegrown edibles to be used in the creation of their breakfast, lunch and dinner.

The large greenhouse, with its selection of Terracotta-potted succulents, is a horticulturists’ haven and also serves as a propagation site for rare plant species.

Those looking to simply relax and unwind can kick back with a book in one of the many relaxation areas dotted throughout the garden, or enjoy a dip in the solar-heated swimming pool. The nearby village centre is brimming with cafés, shops and restaurants, with a slew of beautiful beaches only a short drive away.

More than just a rental villa, Kinghorns Gardens is a destination in itself, with an enchanting garden and modern creature comforts in a to-die-for setting.

Please note The property is not available for events or weddings, as the integrity of the quiet area and surrounding reserve is extremely important to the owners.
Distance from CT 35 minutes
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 4 (minimum two-night say)
Cost From R15 000 per night
(25% discount on rates during June, July, August and September)
Where to find it 3 Nthombeni Way, Gate 2, Noordhoek, Cape Town
MAKE A RESERVATION

title.rendered: Black Eagle Lodges: A Farm Getaway (with Hot Tubs) near Cape Town

content.rendered:
On a privately owned farm just outside the historic town of Caledon, Black Eagle Lodges is home to three country cottages that offer nature-loving travellers an immersive stay surrounded by mountains, a fynbos-dotted valley and abundant birdlife.

Generously spaced a kilometre apart for a heightened sense of peace and privacy, and each boasting their own wood-fired hot tub, the three self-catering units are luxuriously rustic and utterly comfortable, providing exactly what you need for a rejuvenating stay with family and friends.

The views from the hot tub (and the living area and patio) are some of the most spectacular around: a lush-green valley of rolling green hills as far as the eye can see, with your own private dam a stone’s throw from the hot tub.

About the farm

Run by the passionate Delport family for seven generations, Kempsrivier Farm is an established and fully operational sheep, cattle, fruit and wheat farm. While staying at this private paradise, guests are guaranteed a peek at the magnificent birdlife, which includes blue cranes, black eagles (hence the name) and Cape sunbirds. And, if you’re super-lucky, you might even catch a glimpse of the highly elusive Cape leopard.

The lodgings

There are three different units to choose from: a villa and private lodge that each sleep six, and a cottage that sleeps four. All the accommodation is completely off-grid, and each is equipped with private KolKol hot tubs, boasting magnificent countryside views.

  • 3-bedroom villa
  • 3-bedroom private lodge
  • 2-bedroom cottage
  • private hot tubs in each unit
  • indoor fireplaces
  • shaded patio with outdoor seating
  • spacious living rooms
  • indoor and outdoor dining areas
  • braai facilities
  • complimentary wifi in the villa and cottage

While you’re there

Across the lawn is a jetty overhanging your own private dam, perfect for Wim Hoffing before heating up with a relaxing soak in your private hot tub. Those looking to stretch their legs can do so on a scenic walk through the pear and apple orchards or a hike or ride on one of the many trails. Or, simply pull up a chaise longue and spend the afternoon reading or birdwatching.

There is a surfeit of wine farms in Botriver and the Hemel-en-Aarde Valley, and the Hermanus town centre (only a 30 minute drive away) is, of course, brimming with shops, beaches, art galleries and restaurants. Not that you’re going to want to leave the farm…

Distance from CT 1.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free (in villa and cottage only)
Cost Lodge: From R1 800 per night for two people (depending on season)
Cottage: From R2 000 per night for two people (depending on season)
Villa: From R2 500 per night for two people (depending on season)
Where to find it Kempsriver Farm, Caledon, Western Cape

title.rendered: Tsala Treetop Lodge: A Luxury Escape along the Garden Route

content.rendered:
Driving along a dusty farm road just off the N2, near the exclusive seaside resort of Plettenberg Bay, we hardly expected to find a private paradise hidden away in a world of its own.

Within five minutes, we had arrived at our destination – a magical oasis floating above the treetops of an ancient indigenous forest – to be greeted by some inquisitive bushbuck peeking out from behind the greenery, and a flock of tropical birds darting about the crystal-clear skies above us. An apposite welcome indeed.

We paused for a few moments after parking the car to breathe in the country air and take in the expansive panoramas, before following the soothing sounds of trickling water to our home-from-home, Tsala Treetop Lodge, surely one of the Cape’s most beautiful escapes.

A seductive mix of Bali-esque topography and luxe-safari furnishings, the retreat exudes an indescribable aura of mysticism and ancient wonder, with luxurious mod cons reminding us that we were not in fact on an Ancient Javanese island.

The lodgings

Elevated wooden walkways connect 10 suites and six villas, which are equipped with ultimate creature comforts and offer a liberating sense of solitude. Wherever you are in the lodge – sitting in the lounge by the fireplace, relaxing in your private rim-flow pool or enjoying meals in the glass-walled dining room – you’re constantly reminded that you are, in fact, several metres above ground level.

Suite features

  • 10 suites
  • one bedroom with a king-size bed (sleeping 2 adults)
  • en-suite bathroom with a freestanding bath, rain shower and outdoor heated shower
  • spacious indoor seating area
  • wood-burning clay fireplace
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • private front-facing outdoor deck with a seating area
  • second suite-facing outdoor deck with deck chairs and a private plunge pool
  • complimentary canapés and bottle of wine on arrival
  • complimentary minibar items
  • air conditioning and heating
  • complimentary wifi

Villa features

  • 6 villas
  • two bedrooms with a king-size bed (sleeping 4 adults or 2 adults + 2 children)
  • en-suite bathrooms with a rain shower and outdoor heated shower
  • spacious indoor lounge with a dining area
  • wood-burning clay fireplace
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • private front-facing outdoor deck with a seating area
  • second suite-facing outdoor deck with deck chairs and a private plunge pool
  • complimentary canapés and bottle of wine on arrival
  • complimentary minibar items
  • air conditioning and heating
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

The minute you set foot into your suite, you’ll realise you have no intention of ever leaving! Luckily, a sparkling blue rim-flow plunge pool, two resident restaurants, and a view-drenched deck – all on your doorstep – mean you needn’t have to.

The glass-walled Tsala Restaurant serves gourmet breakfasts, light à la carte lunches and to-die-for three-course dinners, rounded off with a curated selection of local wines from the cellar. Those wishing to stay in their dressing gowns and dine in the comfort of their own suite (we don’t blame you!) can opt for room service.

Should you wish to dine at Zinzi Restaurant (for a bistro-dining experience), it’s just a short stroll from the lodge. Your hospitable hosts are always on hand to assist with requests.

And, just in case the heavenly ambience, superb cuisine and surfeit of creature comforts don’t have you relaxed enough, there’s the option of in-room spa treatments available on request.

Adventure lovers will be in their element with the hiking and mountain-biking trails surrounding the property. Or take a short drive into the centre of Plettenberg Bay for boat rides on the Keurbooms River, swimming with African Fur Seals and open-water kayaking. There is also the nearby Birds of Eden sanctuary and Monkeyland Primate Sanctuary, housing 18 species of playful primates.

Part of the esteemed Hunter Hotels group, whose properties are characterised by attention to detail, impeccable service and hard-to-beat locations, Tsala Treetop Lodge most certainly deserves a spot on even the most seasoned of travellers’ lists. Here, you can rest assured that your every desire will be met. And then some.

Distance from CT 6 hours
Child friendly? Yes (villas only) 6 years and older
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free

title.rendered: Forest Valley Cottages: A Treetop Hideaway in Knysna’s Rheenendal Valley

content.rendered:
If you’ve visited Knysna, you will have noticed the dense forests that surround the scattering of homes and guesthouses. A mere 10-minute drive from the centre of town takes you to the Rheenendal Valley, where quiet farm roads and awe-inspiring vistas create a dreamlike setting.

It’s here, perched high above the treetops and overlooking an expanse of rolling hills below, that eight beautifully designed cottages beckon, offering a seductive mix of luxury and intimacy for those seeking a private escape in nature.

Welcoming host Mark Nel ensures every guest has a truly special experience, adding thoughtful additions such as Lindt chocolates on the beds, fresh jasmine in every corner of the room (an irresistible scent in anyone’s books), and a lovely handwritten note wishing guests a fabulous stay – an easy task, given the incredible location and stunning accommodation.

The lodgings

Each cottage boasts unrivalled views of the majestic Outeniqua Mountains and provides a feeling of floating among the treetops – a sea of forest gently swaying beneath you as the wind blows through the trees.

There are seven Honeymoon Suites each sleeping two (Iris, Birdsong, Blue Sky, Sandstone, Gorgeous Olive, Earth Rose and Glory Dawn) and one larger unit sleeping four (Lavender Edge, also popular among honeymooners for its Jacuzzi), each designed to maximise relaxation by allowing the outdoors in.

Cottage features

  • 8 cottages
  • 1 bedroom with a queen-size bed
  • open-plan couple’s shower
  • outdoor Jacuzzi or indoor spa tub
  • indoor wood-burning fireplace
  • fully equipped kitchenette
  • spacious lounge area
  • flat-screen TV with DStv
  • Nespresso machine
  • portable fan or air conditioning (dependent on unit)
  • private deck with seating, either with a hammock, swing chair or loungers, and equipped with an outdoor wood braai or gas Weber
  • daily housekeeping service

While you’re there

Wake up to the sounds of birdsong echoing across the valley, as you enjoy your morning coffee and soak in the view-drenched outdoor spa bath.

The forest walk takes you all the way down into the valley, past an array of flora and fauna, and the ever-popular Kissing Spot, a wooden hide overlooking the treetops, where couples are encouraged to write their names or dedicated love notes on the walls.

When the sun is out, fill a hamper and head out for a scenic picnic at one of the various relaxation spots along the trail, or simply relax with a book by the shared swimming pool. If it’s chilly, curl up by the crackling fire with a glass of red wine.

Those looking to get out and explore can take a short 15 minute drive into the centre of town, brimming with restaurants, bars, shops, Blue Flag beaches (such as Buffalo Bay) and lagoon activities.

Whether you’re seeking an unforgettable spot for a romantic getaway, family break or a soul-enriching solo adventure, Forest Valley ticks the boxes.

Distance from CT 5.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Yes, free
Sleeps 2 per cottage (in 7 units)
4 per cottage (in 1 unit)
Cost From R2 275 per cottage per night (depending on season and cottage type)
Where to find it Rheenendal Ramble 6km from N2, Highway, Knysna

title.rendered: Jus Limin: A Hidden Escape in the Heart of Montagu

content.rendered:
When passionate owners Kai and Alan first laid eyes on the quaint Karoo town of Montagu, it was love at first sight. Having initially laid down roots at Klein Nektar, a peaceful farm just outside of the town centre, the couple decided it was time to branch out on their next venture and opened Jus Limin, a stylish and intimate escape, in July of 2021.

The name, inspired by the pair’s frequent travels to the Caribbean, is a common phrase among islanders, meaning “idly passing time”. And, one look at the spectacular surroundings and the area’s sense of serenity, it’s easy to understand why they chose it.

Surrounded by the breathtaking Langeberg Mountains, the escape is tucked away from prying eyes in the heart of the countryside. A gravel farm road lined with plane trees and iceberg roses leads to the farm, where three individually decorated suites overlook the olive grove.

The lodgings

The “relax” motif runs through each of the three two-sleeper suites, aptly named Chill Out, Take Five and Kick Back.

Chill Out, the most spacious, boasts plush furnishings and a freestanding bath, perfect for a romantic getaway; while Take Five is inspired by the African Bush, with a sheltered private conservatory for relaxing with a good book.

Kick Back has been carefully designed to provide a sense of utter relaxation – with its four-poster bed, combination of antique and modern furnishings, and unique artwork by owner Kai’s sister, Nadja Daehnke.

  • three suites (Chill Out, Take Five and Kick Back)
  • king-size bed
  • en-suite bathroom with a walk-in shower (Chill Out also features a freestanding bath)
  • chaise lounge (Chill Out only) and desk
  • private conservatory with a seating area
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • bar fridge with wine and beers
  • ceiling fans, heating and electric blankets
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

Grab a book or one of the many complimentary magazines and relax under the shade of the pear-tree archway, or throw down a picnic blanket and cushions to savour the view with a relaxing sundowner before heading out for dinner.

The beautifully manicured gardens, dotted with private seating areas and relaxation nooks, are the perfect place to soak up some vitamin D while listening to the sound of birdsong. There’s even a Bamboo Billiard Nook, with a collection of board games and Bar Billiards for those after some fun entertainment.

Feeling peckish? The quaint and ever-popular Kloof Padstal, serving farm-fresh breakfast and lunch options, is right across the road, while a slew of other eateries, coffee shops, local boutiques and art galleries are a mere stroll away.

Whether you’re seeking a scenic space for a solo sojourn, romantic getaway or an intimate escape with a friend or family member, you’ll know you’ve found the perfect place to kick back and relax at Jus Limin.

Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? No
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Free
Cost From R1 500 per suite per night (depending on season)
Where to find it 4 Wichts Street, Montagu, Western Cape

title.rendered: Kwena Lodge at Gondwana: An All-Inclusive Safari on the Garden Route

content.rendered:
Situated near Herbertsdale in the heart of the scenic Garden Route, Gondwana Game Reserve offers a Big 5 safari experience, just over four hours from the centre of Cape Town. In addition to a slew of accommodation offerings, the 11 000-hectare reserve boasts 360-degree views of sweeping fynbos plains and the Langeberg and Outeniqua Mountains in the distance – an appropriately monumental backdrop for an unforgettable escape.

The owners, passionate conservationists Mark and Wendy Rutherford, started this project (converting livestock farms into a malaria-free reserve) in 2005, and it is now home to more than 20 game species including hippo, cheetah, kudu, eland, red hartebeest, lion, giraffe, buffalo and the first wild elephant calves and free-roaming lion cubs born in the region in over 250 years!

The lodgings

Inspired by traditional Khoisan dwellings, the 14 freestanding suites at Kwena Lodge offer front-row seats to two watering holes, overlooking a valley that was formerly part of the supercontinent Gondwanaland, after which the property is named.

The open-plan huts blend seamlessly into the surroundings, and each has a skylight for stargazing from your bed, while the deep baths and closed-combustion fireplaces ensure a toasty space to kick back and relax after your game drives.

In the same vicinity, but in separate buildings, is a lounge and bar, two dining rooms with fireplaces, a shaded verandah and an infinity swimming pool overlooking the animal-dotted plains, an outdoor boma and firepit.

  • 14 freestanding suites
  • king-size bed (can be made into twins)
  • en-suite bathroom with a bath and walk-in shower
  • small seating area
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • skylight
  • closed-combustion fireplace
  • private dressing area
  • private patios with sun loungers
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

Guests are treated to alfresco boma breakfasts, scenic verandah lunch platters, wood-fired evening dinners in the elegant dining room and, of course, sundowner drinks and snacks as the sun dips behind the mountains during your evening game drive.

Nature lovers will be in their element with the fynbos conservation experience, daily game drives, guided bush walks, birdwatching, mountain-biking and stargazing, as well as the popular Junior Ranger Programme for kids. There’s also an on-site Tented Bush Spa, whose variety of Africology treatments can be enjoyed inside, or under the shade of the outdoor spa deck.

Gondwana is one of those immersive escapes that will stay with you long after you leave.

Distance from CT 4.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes (children 6 years and older are allowed on normal game drives, however younger children must be on a private vehicle or, where possible, share with other young families).
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Free
CostFrom R3 920 – R5 035 per person per night (depending on package)
Where to find it R327 Heuningklip Farm, Herbertsdale, Western Cape

title.rendered: SeaPad: A Seaside Escape in a Private Fynbos Estate

content.rendered:
A quick five-minute drive from Gansbaai, on the Cape’s beautiful Whale Coast, lies Romansbaai Beach & Fynbos Estate – a wonderfully secluded wilderness area that’s home to a small scattering of beautiful homes.

It’s here, perched on the edge of a private beach surrounded by fynbos, that this stunning seaside villa takes centre stage. A mere 150 metres from a private beach path, SeaPad (as its name suggests) offers a front-row seat to breathtaking sunsets, with sounds of the crashing waves creating the soporific soundtrack.

Part of the exclusive Romansbaai Collection, the luxury home was passionately designed by KTA Architects in collaboration with Hildi & Co Interiors, who have given it a decidedly contemporary feel, with warm accents softening the pared-back interiors.

The lodgings

SeaPad sleeps four guests in two bedrooms. Floor-to-ceiling windows in the spacious open-plan living area offer 180-degree panoramas of the spectacular surrounds, while the view-drenched outdoor deck is the perfect place to soak up the scene.

Villa features


  • one master bedroom on the ground floor
  • one guest room with a private patio on the top floor
  • en-suite bathrooms
  • open-plan fully equipped kitchen with an induction stove, dishwasher and fridge/freezer
  • sea-facing bedrooms, dining and lounge areas
  • view-drenched outdoor deck with a swimming pool
  • gas braai and charcoal Weber
  • Nespresso coffee machine (pods)
  • wine cooler
  • B&O music system

The high-tech amenities (such as remote-operated blinds and shutters) and the good-quality finishes make this an effortless seaside getaway.

Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? No
Pet friendly? No
Wifi? Free
Cost of special From R7 000 per night (sleeps 4)
Where to find it Romansbaai Beach & Fynbos Estate, Dangerpoint, Western Cape

title.rendered: Cederberg Ridge Wilderness Lodge: A Modern African Farm Stay

content.rendered:
Stealthily tucked into the foothills of the Cederberg Mountains, Cederberg Ridge is an intimate nine-roomed lodge, where warm, emotionally intelligent service, sumptuous accommodation and delicious food coalesce to create an unforgettable stay.

But it’s the lodge’s unrivalled setting – on a 3 000-hectare fruit farm in the heart of the Cederberg Wilderness Reserve – that knocks it out of the park. Characterised by untamed landscapes, red-sandstone mountains, ancient rock art and flaming sunsets, the Cederberg emanates a kind of otherworldly majesty and sacred solitude you’ll be hard-pressed to find anywhere else in the world.

And even though the town of Clanwilliam is a mere eight kilometres away, the hotel’s surreptitious perch on a mountainside creates a sense of utter seclusion where you can – G&T in hand – soak up the raw and rugged beauty of the untamed surroundings.

The lodgings

The rooms are light, bright and utterly luxurious, with earthy hues and natural textures creating a pared-back aesthetic that plays second fiddle to the spectacular surroundings.

  • 11 spacious suites with indoor and outdoor showers and a large terrace
  • 3 luxury suites with free-standing bath, indoor and outdoor shower and a large stone terrace
  • 1 honeymoon suite that can also be used as a two-bedroom sharing suite with a central sitting room and indoor and outdoor showers
  • 2 pool suites with a large terrace, plunge pool and a romantic sleep-out option on your terrace
  • 3 superior suites with a large deck and walk-through shower
  • 2 classic rooms (one of which is wheelchair accessible)
  • wood-burning fireplaces in select suites
  • TV with DStv
  • large swimming pool overlooking the mountains
  • in-room spa treatments available
  • complimentary wifi
  • main library with fireplace, books

A world of adventure

After enjoying a ’berg-to-plate breakfast on the sun-dappled deck, allow your days to unfold however you choose: with a chilled game of boules or croquet, lounging by the pool or with a spot of afternoon wine-tasting…

Adventure seekers will want to take full advantage of the striking surroundings, whether it be a guided or self-guided hike around the reserve, mountain biking, a San rock-art tour, tubing on the dam, or star-gazing around the fire pit at night.

Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes, however, children under 6 years need special permission
Pet friendly? No
Cost From R2 700 per person sharing (August – 20 December 2022)
Where to find it Cederberg Ridge, Old Klawer Road, Clanwilliam, Western Cape

title.rendered: Lekkerwater Beach Lodge: A Sea-Scraping Lodge on the Garden Route

content.rendered:
Dubbed the “jewel of the Western Cape”, De Hoop Nature Reserve is a 34 000-hectare conservancy, where miles of untouched nature, billowing sand dunes, and unencumbered sea views set the scene for some of the best whale-watching in the world!

Cradled in this expansive bay of natural beauty lies Lekkerwater Beach Lodge, an upscale seaside escape that promises a level of privacy and exclusivity from which to soak up your next-level beach safari.

Meaning “good water” in Afrikaans, Lekkerwater’s drawcard is undoubtedly its unrivalled seaside setting. Ensconced in a blanket of fynbos-covered dunes, the lodge blends seamlessly with its environment: a five-kilometre-long private beach offering the kind of beauty you’d be hard-pressed to find anywhere else in the world.

Crashing waves, the smell of the ocean, flaming sunsets and possible sightings of whales and dolphins set the scene for a truly one-of-a-kind experience.

The lodgings

In keeping with its pristine backdrop, each of the six individual off-grid suites are utterly comfortable, while upholding the integrity of the setting – you won’t find TVs or air-conditioners here. The luxury is in the spectacular setting – where guests are encouraged to relax and embrace life’s cherished and simple pleasures.

  • 6 standalone suites sleeping 2 each; the family suites sleeps 2 adults and 2 children
  • en-suite bathrooms with a shower
  • indoor fireplace in each room
  • private sea-facing deck in each suite
  • open-plan shared lounge, bar and dining area in the main lodge
  • wraparound deck with outdoor seating
  • shared swimming pool and firepit
  • complimentary wifi (in the suites only)

While you’re there

So how do you fill your days so far from civilisation? During summer, we recommend taking a leisurely stroll along the beach before enjoying a dip in a tidal pool and a picnic on a secluded sand dune.

When the mercury drops, pull up a seat on the ocean-facing deck and whale-spot to your heart’s content with a glass of fine local wine in your hand (season is from July to November).

There are also Lekkerwater’s unique and informative land-based marine-safari experiences that take guests on coastal walks to explore the rockpools and intertidal ecosystems, spotting cetaceans offshore as you go.

Lekkerwater lies in the heart of the majestic Cape Floral Kingdom, so extensive biodiversity is a given.

History buffs should put their names down for the paleontology talks and demonstrations, led by the small team of passionate and highly knowledgeable naturalists.

Whether you choose to lie back and let the ocean-facing setting wash over you, or you decide to go and explore the magnificent coastline, you’re guaranteed to make lifetime memories at Lekkerwater Beach Lodge.

Distance from CT 3.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes, for 6 years and over
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it De Hoop Nature Reserve, Western Cape

title.rendered: STIL: A Contemporary Escape in Montagu Where Style + Serenity Converge

content.rendered:
Set against the Langeberg Mountains, the Klein Karoo town of Montagu has both pastoral and high-street appeal, with vineyards and orchards punctuating the landscape, and a town centre lined with shops, cafés and art galleries.

Offering an undeniable sense of escapism and tranquility, it’s no wonder Hanno and Martly Calitz decided to create STIL – an escape for those wishing to experience the striking surrounds in a spectacular spot.

A curated experience

Guest experience is at the heart of STIL’s offering. As such, visitors have the option of being left to their own devices in complete privacy, or may choose a curated itinerary.

The itinerary includes private catering, guided hikes, rock climbing, mountain-biking, art classes, bubbly and wine tastings and more. There is also a small, experienced team of beauty therapists available, offering a carefully considered menu of skincare and body treatments designed for relaxation and rejuvenation that can be pre-booked.

With two fireplaces (one in the bedroom and one in the lounge), STIL is also perfect for a romantic winter getaway. Escape Cape Town’s rainy season, and relish blue skies, long walks and towering mountains all around.

Artful endeavours

Hanno and Martly’s love of art is evident; they’ve transformed the surrounding wild grass into an ever-evolving sculpture garden (featuring several intricate works by renowned South African artist Anton Smit) that fits seamlessly with the home’s white-painted walls, terracotta floors and wooden accents. It’s certainly a dream destination for those who love architecture, art and design.

The lodgings

Designed for two adults and two children, STIL offers a wonderfully intimate place for couples or small families to kick back and enjoy one other’s company in style. The interiors are contemporary yet soft-edged, with a wonderful indoor-outdoor flow. What’s more, you can also bring your fur children, as STIL is proudly pet-friendly.

  • one bedroom with a king-size bed and indoor fireplace (cot or mattress for 2 children on request)
  • en-suite bathroom with a shower
  • open-plan interior with a lounge, fully equipped kitchen, and dining area with an indoor fireplace (wood provided)
  • selection of carefully curated books
  • outdoor patio with a seating area, an umbrella and a Weber braai
  • view-drenched rooftop area
  • heated plunge pool
  • swimming towels
  • air conditioning in the bedroom and lounge-dining area
  • complimentary wifi

While you’re there

  • hiking and mountain-biking trails
  • culinary experiences at STIL or in town (walking distance)
  • ghost tour
  • birdwatching
  • wine and bubbly tastings
  • pampering (massages, reflexology and body therapies)
  • rock climbing
  • local farmers’ market
  • guided town tour
  • day excursions to nearby smalltowns of McGregor, Barrydale, Swellendam and Robertson
  • dried fruit, olives and medicinal herb experiences
  • hot springs
  • art meander to galleries and studio
  • art classes
  • breakfast, lunch and dining options

“Our dream was to design a private and tranquil getaway catering to guests’ individual needs,” say the owners. Well, they certainly got that right!

Good to know STIL is listed as one of Inside Guide’s Top 10 Romantic Escapes in the Cape for 2022. To discover all of our Top 200 Experiences, buy your copy now!
Distance from Cape Town 2.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes (2 small children)
Pet friendly? Yes
Where to find it 1A Bath Street, Montagu, Western Cape
Cost From R3 500 per night for the house (depending on season)
Minimum two-night stay.

title.rendered: Ludus Magnus: An Olympian Hotel + Playground on a Farm in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
We should have known we were entering an Olympian Wonderland before we even arrived at Ludus Magnus. Named after an Ancient Roman gladiator training school, this five-star guesthouse beautifully positioned between Franschhoek, Stellenbosch and Paarl is home to an eye-watering array of cutting-edge amenities and activities all of which revealed themselves in the most charming of ways during a recent stay here.

The farm is owned by a French-Italian husband-and-wife team who bought the land a few years ago when they moved to Franschhoek from Europe and have been developing it – from scratch – ever since. Well-versed in luxury and hospitality.

Let the games begin

There are eight tidy and tastefully appointed en-suite rooms named after streets in Ancient Rome and three two-bedroom luxury villas, with private pools, a beautifully spacious reception area, and an upstairs dining room with beautiful views. It’s only when you happen upon the palm-tree-lined pool do you get an inkling that this is no ordinary resort… The pool is 25 metres long, with training lanes and, for those venturing beneath the surface, a series of serendipitous messages (courtesy of the owners’ 14-year-old daughter) stuck to the bottom that read: “Stay insane or go crazy”; “Think big”; “Never give up”; “Believe”; “Dream” and “Make today amazing”.

The Olympian theme continues with a 400-metre horse track, state-of-the-art sports field and a dam with 50-metre-long training lanes! Why, you might well ask? One of the owners was a professional athlete in his former life, and wanted to offer guests world-class facilities to train while on holiday. There’s even an altitude chamber in the pipeline!

Springbokkies, donkeys + vitamin C

Upon entering the reception area, a Bryan Habana-signed Springbok effigy greets you (the former World Cup star was one of Ludus’s first guests when it opened a few months ago and the family are clearly staunch Springbok supporters). There are also three springboks living on the farm, in addition to four rescue donkeys – “I found them on the N2,” recalls the owner, “disease-ridden and emaciated, and could not leave them behind.”

The off-the-grid property is also planted with over 7 000 trees – a mix of plums, avocados, litchis, mangoes, pears, apples, grapes, bananas, macadamia nuts and olives – all of which were added by the couple when they arrived four years ago. There’s even a citrus grove – dubbed “The Vitamin C Trail” – with everything from lemons and limes, to grapefruits, naartjies, clementines and oranges. The aim is for the property to become completely self-sustaining.

Leisure island

Should you feel like some beach time, a white-sand island – complete with a pizza oven, deck chairs, a tree-shaded hammock and rowboat – is the ideal spot to live out your Robinson Crusoe fantasies, followed by some 50-metre laps in the dam.

There’s even a river with white-water rapids – in the middle of Franschhoek, nog al – where the owners’ intrepid eight-year-old son took us on the most epic tubing adventure through the Vieux Riche Valley.

The whole is greater than the sum of its parts

To adapt a concept coined by Ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle, all of Ludus’ seemingly disparate parts – a five-star hotel, four rescue donkeys, 7 000 fruit trees, three springbokke, 1.5 hectares of shiraz vineyards, a 400-metre running track, and so on – make complete and utter sense when you meet the makers. And not only that, all of the individual elements, while impressive in their own right, hang together so harmoniously, and together elevate the entire experience to an unforgettable stay.

The lodgings

  • three two-bedroom luxury villas with private pools
  • Main House with eight en-suite rooms (Aurelia, Cassia, Appia, Casalina, Emilia, Flaminia, Postumia and Salaria named after Italian roads)
  • high-speed complimentary wifi
  • flat-screen TV
  • Le Creuset-equipped kitchen
  • spacious reception area
  • restaurant (private chef on request)
  • professional butler
  • expansive garden
  • mobile spa
  • 50-metre swimming lanes
  • 25-metre swimming pool
  • 400m running track
  • full-sized rugby field
  • exclusive riverside deck
  • daily airport transfer
  • daily cleaning service
  • altitude chamber (in the pipeline)

Cost From R6 900 per room per night (Manor House) (depending on season)
From R20 700 per villa per night (depending on season)
From R162 920 (exclusive-use, depending on season, sleeps 34)
Minimum two-night stay
Distance from CT 1 hour 15 mins
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Two Rivers Farm, Franschhoek, Western Cape
