title.rendered: Southern Yurts: A Unique Glamping Experience in The Overberg

content.rendered:
It’s no secret that glamping, or luxury camping, is more popular than ever for those seeking a one-of-a-kind, close-to-nature experience (without the sleeping-on-the-floor part). And, if you thought cabins and canvas tents were the only options, think again: you can now gaze up at the stars through the crown of a magnificent yurt.

Once the standard choice of accommodation for nomads in Mongolia, Siberia and Turkey, yurts (circular tents made of felt or skin on a collapsible framework) have made their way onto our mountains – a first-of-its-kind in South Africa – thanks to Cape Town manufacturer, Southern Yurts.

Located in the Diepklowe Nature Conservancy on Porcupine Hills Guest Farm, a short drive from Bot River, the collection of private yurts are immersed in endless nature, providing a get-away-from-it-all escape.

The lodgings

Made from wooden beams draped in canvas, yurts offer all the amenities of a luxury camp, without any of the dust and schlep associated with DIY camping. In addition to Forest View Yurt (in its own secret location), two more yurt accommodations: Malachite and Kestrel.

Forest View Yurt

Perfect for couples

  • indoor fireplace and fan/heater
  • enclosed outdoor bathroom with hot shower
  • deck overlooking the valley
  • enclosed open-plan kitchen
  • wood-fired hot tub

Malachite and Kestrel Camp

Perfect for groups

  • Malachite camp, sleeping four
  • Kestrel camp sleeping two (includes a wood-fired hot tub)
  • private bedrooms
  • private bathrooms
  • each unit has a private kitchen and bathroom
  • spacious lounging space
  • outdoor braai area

With the Forest View Yurt situated on a north-facing slope of the conservancy, next to the reserve’s “secret forest”, and the other camp hidden at the base of a cliff in the valley, the yurts provide majestic views of every sunrise and sunset, and offer front-row seats to the surrounding flora, fauna and abundant birdlife.

While you’re there

Should you tire of sitting on your own private deck under the stars, the farm offers countless activities: swing under an ancient oak tree, venture out on one of the many hikes, birdwatch, take a dip in your private hot tub or enjoy a sundowner on the floating raft in the dam.

For those with more time to kill, take a zipline through the Overberg mountains with Cape Canopy Tours, go horse-riding or go wine-tasting at one of the nearby wine farms.

There’s hardly a better way to get away from it all than waking up to the sounds of birds, and falling asleep under the stars.

Good to know Two new cabins opened in October
Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? Yes, on request
Pet friendly? Yes, Forest View Yurt allows pets by prior arrangement (additional fee of R100) but the other camps are not pet-friendly due to its proximity to a pair of breeding black eagles.
Where to find it Diepklowe Private Nature Reserve, 113/7 Van der Stel Pass Road, Bot River
Cost From R1 300 per unit per night (depending on season and unit type)
Minimum 2 night stay required on weekends.

title.rendered: Melozhori Game Reserve: Wildlife-Spotting From Your Private Pod

content.rendered:
It’s late-afternoon at Melozhori Game Reserve. I pour myself a glass of bubbly before sinking into the hot tub on the deck of our private pod. My travel companions (husband and five-year-old son) have headed off on their mountain bikes to catch a closeup of the herd of buffalo we’d spotted on our game drive earlier, leaving me all alone. The silence and solitude of the sun-drenched savannah are soporific.

Though it’s just a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Cape Town, this 2 500-hectare game reserve near Bonnievale feels like it’s a million miles away. Ahead of me, an acacia-shaded valley extends to the Riviersonderend Mountains in the distance; chirping birds and rustling leaves (as the occasional gecko darts about seeking shade) are the only sounds about.

I lie back and allow the events of the day to sink in: a herd of wildebeest romping boisterously on the open plains, giraffes browsing nonchalantly, zebras play fighting, and some stealthy-looking birds of prey circling overhead about to go in for the kill. There’s something about watching animals in their natural habitat…

A movement on the escarpment wakes me from near-slumber. I gaze up to catch a perfectly choreographed herd of springbok hopping across the veld in unison, the last rays of sun catching their backsides to produce a dazzling spectacle. A matinee to end all matinees – enjoyed from the comfort of my own private hot tub.

About Melozhori Private Game Reserve

Founded by the Bhorat family in 2008, the private game reserve (once part of the historic wagon route) lies in the majestic Cape Fold Mountains in the Overberg.

Following considerate rehabilitation efforts, the reserve has since expanded into 2 500 hectares of sweeping plains where Karoo succulents, mountainous fynbos and Renosterveld offer the perfect grazing ground for a slew of wildlife – comprising 19 different mammal species and 131 identified birds.

Visitors can expect to see the incredibly rare yet beautiful sable antelope, as well as giraffe, zebra, wildebeest, kudu, eland, oryx and bontebok, to name a few. The Cape leopard has also been spotted here on rare occasion.

Guests are welcomed by hands-on managers Lientjie and Coenraad Nell and their assistant Marzanne du Plessis, who are only a Whatsapp away should you require anything.

The lodgings

Two brand-new pods (Valley Pod and Waterfall Pod) perch on an untouched area of the reserve that overlooks the game-dotted plains beyond, offering an ideal setting for a private escape or romantic retreat.

In addition to the pods, there is an all-inclusive luxury lodge with four en-suite bedrooms and a rim-flow pool as well as a stunning two-bedroom self-catering cottage with a wood-fired hot tub, a sparkling pool and an outdoor braai.

The pods

  • one bedroom and a sleeper couch, sleeping two adults and a small child
  • en-suite bathroom with a bath and shower
  • open-plan kitchenette with an oven, microwave, stove, fridge and tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • open-plan lounge and dining area with an indoor fireplace
  • outdoor deck with a braai and seating area
  • wood-fired hot tub
  • 14-metre hammock
  • wood-fired pizza oven
  • air conditioning
  • complimentary wifi

Cost From R3 500 per pod per night
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

The cottage

  • two bedrooms, able to accommodate four adults and two children
  • en-suite bathrooms with a bath and shower
  • private deck leading off each bedroom
  • fully equipped spacious kitchen
  • open-plan lounge and dining area with an indoor fireplace
  • outdoor deck with a braai, fire pit and seating area
  • wood-fired hot tub
  • private swimming pool
  • hammock
  • air conditioning
  • complimentary wifi

Cost From R3 000 – R3 500 per night for the cottage (depending on season)
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

The lodge

  • four luxury suites including two family suites
  • en-suite bathrooms with a bath and shower
  • in-room fireplace
  • private deck with sun loungers
  • shared open-plan lounge
  • shared bar and dining area
  • shared outdoor deck with a swimming pool
  • outdoor boma and fireplace
  • outdoor seating and relaxation area
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • air conditioning
  • complimentary wifi

Please note The lodge can only be booked in its entirety, not on a per-room basis. At least three to five days’ notice is required for lodge bookings depending on the group size.
Cost From R18 000 per night for the lodge (1 to 4 guests)
From R4 500 per night per person thereafter (maximum 8 guests)
MAKE A RESERVATION

While you’re there

  • game drives
  • nature walks
  • Birdwatching
  • Mountain biking (wondrous terrain and views; bicycles can be rented on the reserve for those who don’t have their own)
  • surrounding wine farms
  • Cape Agulhas, the southernmost tip of Africa
  • Hermanus for whale-watching in season; shops and restaurants

Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No

title.rendered: Bartholomeus Klip: Exceptional Hospitality at a Farmstead in the Riebeek Valley

content.rendered:
Like a scene straight out of The Crown, Bartholomeus Klip (or BK as it is affectionately known) is a charming Victorian-era homestead situated on a working wheat and sheep farm amid the 10 000-hectare Elandsberg Nature Reserve. In addition to a vast farm dam, a boathouse chockful of watersports gear, a waterside restaurant and endless access to nature, each of the three accommodation offerings is home to a magnificent garden planted with rose bushes, bougainvillaea, clivia, hydrangea, plumbago, daffodils, heartsease, forget-me-nots, and more.

We visited during the pandemic and even though the restaurant was closed, and human contact was kept to a minimum, we were met by an overarching sense of warmth and largesse. General manager Lesley Gillett, who’s been with the property for 21 years, ensured that the house was stocked with all the basics, and more: good olive oil and balsamic vinegar, Bean There filter coffee, in addition to a tray of Nespresso pods and two varieties of home-baked melt-in-your-mouth rusks.

A highlight of our stay was returning to our cottage after a morning spent canoeing, swimming and SUPing to find a delectable afternoon tea spread of freshly baked scones and the hugest (and most delicious) lemon meringue pie we’ve ever encountered, courtesy of in-house chef Louise Gillett (Lesley’s twin sister).

About the farm

The Parker family, who have owned Bartholomeus Klip for more than 85 years (they bought it from a friend in 1936), are passionate conservationists and environmentalists. As such, the property has a firm focus on responsible tourism, commitment to the environment and community care, with the owners (and Elandsberg Game Reserve as a whole) leading efforts towards all aspects of social and environmental upliftment.

Fans of the Netflix series The Crown may or may not know that episode 2 of the first season was filmed at Bartholomeus Klip – which offers some indication of what’s on offer at this magnificent property: wide-open spaces, beautifully appointed cottages and gardens worthy of Anne of Green Gables.

On an early-morning run, we stumbled upon an epitaph to Reginald Park (grandfather of current owner, Duncan), which captures the spirit of Bartholomeus Klip: “Let the land speak,” it reads – a powerful commitment to preserving the environment.

The lodgings

There are three accommodation offerings: The Farmhouse (exuding old-world charm with its antique furniture, lofty proportions and plush furnishings and upholstery); Wild Olive House (a self-catering cottage, perfect for private getaways with family or friends); and Heron House (the latest addition, ideal for larger groups as it sleeps up to 12 adults).

The Farmhouse

  • four en-suite double bedrooms with a bath and shower
  • one separate suite outside sleeping two
  • spacious lounge with an indoor fireplace
  • wrap-around verandah overlooking the garden
  • four-course dinner
  • afternoon tea
  • snacks and sundowners
  • early-morning coffee and pastries
  • two daily nature drives
  • use of mountain bikes, canoes and other facilities
  • complimentary wifi
  • Nespresso machine

Child friendly? No
Pet-friendly? No
Cost From R2 600 per person per night

Wild Olive House

  • two bedrooms with separate bathrooms and a room with bunk beds
  • an adjoining cottage that sleeps two
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • large shaded verandah
  • private garden
  • swimming pool
  • outdoor braai
  • use of mountain bikes, canoes and other facilities
  • complimentary wifi
  • Nespresso machine
  • pantry orders can be made via the online ordering system to stock the fridge prior to arrival

Child friendly? Yes
Pet-friendly? No
Cost From R4 145 per night (sleeps 6 adults and 2 children)

Heron House

The latest addition to Bartholomeus Klip, Heron House is ideal for larger groups (it sleeps up to 12 adults) on a self-catering basis. The verandah, with its pool, outdoor seating area and braai facilities, boasts exquisite views of the farm and is perfect for effortless entertaining.

  • five en-suite bedrooms with a bath and shower, and a loft area with a double sleeper couch
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • large shaded verandah
  • private garden with outdoor seating area
  • swimming pool
  • outdoor braai
  • use of mountain bikes, canoes and other facilities
  • complimentary wifi
  • Nespresso machine
  • pantry orders can be made via the online ordering system to stock the fridge prior to arrival

Child friendly? Yes
Pet-friendly? No
Cost From R6 204 per night (sleeps 12)

The Restaurant at Bartholomeus Klip

Bartholomeus Klip is known for its food. Helmed by chef Louise Gillett, who has been at the farm for 19 years, the waterside restaurant serves honest-to-goodness, seasonally driven meals to guests and day visitors alike. Booking is essential.

View the menu

A reservoir of activities

While relaxation might be at the top of your list when you choose to stay at Bartholomeus Klip, there’s a surprising selection of activities you will want to take advantage of.

  • swimming in the dam and pools
  • guided nature drives
  • meet the quaggas
  • visit the endangered tortoise sanctuary
  • mountain biking
  • hiking
  • fishing
  • canoeing, kayaking and windsurfing
  • farm tours
  • day visits with guided nature drives

Bartholomeus Klip ticks all the boxes for an authentic farm stay that’s not too far from Cape Town.

Distance from Cape Town 1.5 hours
Where to find it Elandsberg Farms, Bo Hermon Road, Hermon
BOOK DIRECT

title.rendered: La Clé Lodge: Five-Star Farm Luxury in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
Among sweeping vineyards and beautiful gardens, La Clé des Montagnes Lodge is the epitome of a sequestered farm stay.

The Cape Dutch interiors (courtesy of Jacques Erasmus of Hemelhuijs), coupled with

a tennis court, helipad, duck ponds, water features, and lush lawns as far as the eye can see, make this the ultimate hideaway – not to mention a team of experienced chefs on hand to tend to all your dining desires.

Haute home comforts

Exuding all the charm of a cosy country manor (with all the modern creature comforts, of course), this five-bedroom lodge is decked out in a stylish mix of contemporary and traditional decor.

The spacious living and entertaining areas, complete with a traditional farmhouse kitchen and a large swimming pool, make it the ideal place for an extended-family getaway.

The home is available to book on a per-room or exclusive-use basis. There are two king-size Garden Rooms, two king-size Petite Rooms and one king-size Courtyard Room (all en-suite), which can be made into twins on request.

Garden rooms

  • two Garden Rooms sleeping two each
  • en-suite bathroom with a shower and free-standing bath
  • king-size bed (can be converted to twin beds)
  • small seating area
  • private patio leading out onto the garden
  • TV with select DStv channels
  • in-room safe
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • complimentary snacks
  • heated towel rails
  • complimentary wifi

Cost From R9 350 per room per night (depending on season)

Courtyard room

  • one courtyard room sleeping two
  • en-suite bathroom with a rain shower
  • king-size bed (can be converted to twin beds)
  • small seating area and desk
  • private terrace and access to garden
  • TV with select DStv channels
  • in-room safe
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • complimentary snacks
  • heated towel rails
  • complimentary wifi

Cost From R7 950 per room per night (depending on season)

Petite rooms

  • two petite loft-style rooms sleeping two each
  • en-suite bathroom with a shower and free-standing bath
  • king-sized bed (can be converted to twin beds)
  • small seating area
  • TV with select DStv channels
  • in-room safe
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities
  • complimentary snacks
  • heated towel rails
  • complimentary wifi

Cost From R6 250 per room per night (depending on season)

Heavenly highlights

At La Clé, relaxation is the order of the day. Unwind in the beautifully landscaped garden, or by the pool with a good book and a glass of wine. Or why not enjoy a massage from the in-house masseuse, or explore the slew of cultural attractions, quaint shops and award-winning restaurants in the town centre (a short walk away)?

Ideally suited to a romantic escape for two, an extended getaway with the kids or an unforgettable celebration (with the breathtaking setting to match), La Clé Lodge is the ultimate spot to soak up the magic of the Franschhoek Valley.

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? Yes, over the age of 12
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it 32 Cabriere Street, Franschhoek, Western Cape

title.rendered: Nibbana: An Unforgettable Farm Stay in Tulbagh

content.rendered:
Tulbagh was never on my list. Neither was Wolseley. I mean, I love a rural farming hamlet as much as the next person, but given the choice between a beach holiday/ game farm/ ski trip/ city escape, I’ll pick the beach every day of the week. The most exhilarating moments in my life, and the memories I cherish most, all revolve around the ocean.

That was until we visited Nibbana… More than just a farm, Nibbana is an experience… or rather a series of epic experiences you won’t soon forget.

The setting

Flanked by two towering mountain ranges in the Witzenberg Valley near Tulbagh, this 190-hectare working farm is the picture of bucolic paradise. Handwritten signs along a dusty farm road lead to a stylish manor house and a smattering of farm cottages, beyond which horse paddocks and grazing sheep complete the storybook scene.

A short walk further up the dirt road, you’ll stumble upon the farm’s pièce de résistance: an enchanting Secret Garden. Archways of ancient cypress, eucalyptus and oak trees create natural tunnelled pathways that lead to a sylvan paradise, where a trickling stream, natural rock pool, life-size wooden sculptures, hammocks and a 10-seater dining table with a pizza oven await.

We spent most of our days here, rock-hopping, swimming and lazing in hammocks on the sun-dappled deck to the sound of croaking frogs, chirping birds and oak leaves rustling in the breeze.

These are the moments I haven’t been able to stop thinking about:

  • floating on our backs – and watching the clouds drift by – in the sparkling green, tree-lined farm dam
  • sitting on a couch on the deep verandah in the early morning, sipping coffee and eating home-baked rusks, with blankets wrapped around our shoulders
  • taking long walks along the dusty farm road at dusk, without seeing or hearing another soul
  • red wine-fuelled stargazing sessions to the sound of a crackling fire

The lodgings

With the Tulbagh Winelands right on its doorstep, this sumptuous retreat offers various accommodation types and is ideal for those seeking a luxurious getaway in nature. Master-of-all-trades interior designer Don McCarthy has created an acutely unique artistic-farmhouse vibe matched by an exacting attention to luxurious detail.

(Think deep verandahs, a colour-coded antique bookcase, built-in fireplaces, oversized, sumptuous furniture, beautifully folded monogrammed towels, super-comfortable king-size beds, high-thread-count linen, Rain toiletries). A breezy lack of stuffiness ties everything together beautifully, creating stylish yet cosy lodgings.

The Manor House

  • four bedrooms (namely the Master, Green, Grey and Twin room) sleeping eight
  • king-size beds (except in the Twin and Grey rooms), with mosquito nets and electric blankets
  • en-suite bathrooms with a bath and shower
  • fully equipped designer kitchen
  • spacious living area and dining area with indoor fireplaces
  • large outdoor terrace and dining area
  • braai area and sun deck
  • large private pool and garden
  • complimentary tea and coffee
  • complimentary wifi
  • bluetooth speaker
  • all linen, towels and toiletries provided

Sleeps 8 (exclusive-use only)
Cost From R 6 000 per night for the house (depending on season)

Stable Family Cottage

  • three-bedroom en-suite cottage sleeping six
  • king-size beds in all rooms (can be converted into two single beds)
  • mosquito nets and electric blankets in the master bedroom
  • bathrooms with showers
  • large modern kitchen and living area with a dining table
  • fireplace in lounge and a wood-burning stove in the kitchen
  • two large outdoor terraces and a braai area
  • private plunge pool
  • complimentary tea and coffee
  • complimentary wifi
  • bluetooth speaker
  • all linen, towels and toiletries provided

Sleeps 6
Cost From R4 200 per night for the cottage (depending on season)

Stable Studio Cottage

  • spacious open-plan suite sleeping two adults
  • king-size bed (can be converted into two single beds), with a mosquito net and electric blanket
  • en-suite bathroom with a shower
  • indoor living area with armchairs and a fireplace
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • two large outdoor terraces and a braai area
  • private plunge pool
  • complimentary tea and coffee
  • complimentary wifi
  • al linen, towels, shower soap and toilet paper provided

Sleeps 2
Cost From R2 100 per night for the cottage (depending on season)

Karoo cottage

  • spacious one-bedroom honeymoon cottage sleeping two
  • king-size bed with a mosquito net and electric blanket
  • en-suite bathroom with a shower
  • lounge with a couch, fireplace, coffee table and desk
  • fully equipped kitchen with a dining table
  • large outdoor terrace and fire pit
  • wood-fired private plunge pool and hot tub
  • complimentary tea and coffee
  • complimentary wifi
  • all linen, towels and toiletries

Sleeps 2
Cost From R2 100 per night for the cottage (depending on season)

While you’re there…

  • Secret Garden with large oak trees, bubbling streams, flowers and sculptures
  • hammocks
  • outdoor wood-fired pizza oven
  • swimming in the natural pool and two nearby dams
  • rowboat at the dam
  • catch-and-release fishing on request
  • private waterfall
  • Horse About horse-riding trails for beginners and up
  • hiking and mountain-biking trails
  • nearby Ceres Zipline
  • birdwatching

Distance from CT 1.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Boontjiesrivier Road, Wolseley, Western Cape

title.rendered: The Greenhouse at Fazenda: A Romantic Forest Retreat in Swellendam

content.rendered:
At the foot of the Langeberg Mountains lies South Africa’s third-oldest town: Swellendam, a charming parish, home to a quaint collection of original Cape Dutch buildings, historical churches, art galleries and museums. In recent years, a clutch of acclaimed restaurants, coffee shops and boutique hotels have opened in the area, making it a popular stop-over for travellers en-route to Knysna and Plett.

Fazenda is one such property. Hidden in the breathtaking Hermitage Valley just outside of town, this secluded – and utterly romantic – retreat beckons.

Situated on the edge of a working farm, among towering pines, with the Langeberg mountains beyond, the escape is host to three stylish cottages (Forest Retreat, Ultimate Retreat and Perfect Escape), each overlooking a sparkling dam and, most recently, the otherworldly Greenhouse.

The lodgings

Immersed in the shade of a secret forest, The Greenhouse is an open-plan cabin lined with double-volume glass panes that boast 360-degree views of the stunning surrounds. The tranquil hideaway is completely out of sight of other guests, offering an ideal location to unplug and unwind in sumptuous (socially distanced) style.

  • one en-suite bedroom with a king-size bed
  • open-plan living area and dining area
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • private outdoor sundeck with a braai and outdoor seating
  • private plunge pool
  • complimentary wifi

On your doorstep

During summer, your private plunge pool is the perfect place to cool down after a hike or cycle on one of the many mountain trails. There are also numerous rock pools and a natural swimming dam for mid-adventure dips, while the lush forest is perfect for alfresco picnics. And neighbouring Swellendam is a heritage-rich and restaurant-dotted outing for those looking to immerse themselves in local culture and cuisine.

With nothing but the sounds of nature to punctuate the peaceful silence, this mountainside escape is a forest fantasy.

Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? No
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Fazenda, Hermitage Valley, Swellendam, Western Cape

title.rendered: Mosaic Lagoon Lodge: An Intimate Escape Near Stanford

content.rendered:
An ancient milkwood tree lies at the heart – physically and figuratively – of this discreet five-bedroomed lodge tucked away on a private fynbos reserve near Stanford. Spanning 1 000 hectares, the property is home to a flourishing bird sanctuary, a dreamy lagoon and river, and an enchanting milkwood forest inside which Mosaic Lagoon Lodge is hidden.

With a spa, boutique, lagoon-facing restaurant, and a string of exhilarating activities, this ecocentric destination is where city-weary travellers go for a secluded, restorative stay in nature, knowing they’ll leave feeling content and energised.

A lodge for all seasons

We first visited Mosaic Lagoon Lodge during winter in 2019 and, though we enjoyed gorgeous sunny weather that allowed us to partake in all the exhilarating outdoor activities, the setting reminded us of the Old West (“We kind of expected to see a masked Lone Ranger and Tonto galloping by on horseback. So surreal is the setting, it feels like a film set.”)

In summer, the lagoon tells a different story. A flurry of windsurfers, water-skiers and kite-surfers dot the water, creating a chilled, summer-holiday vibe, with flocks of perennially beautiful flamingos roosting on the glassy water all year round.

The lodge has seen a change in ownership since our initial sojourn: long-time associate Maryke De Villiers took over the reins from Tennessee-based couple Kathryn and Breese Johnson in October 2019.

The lodgings


David Rogers

A wooden walkway connects all five of the African-safari-style bungalows to the central dining area. As an eco-driven and environmentally conscious lodge, the “local is lekker” thread runs deep: from the Kalahari toiletries in the bathrooms to the ingredients chefs Adrian Boshoff and Gift Madzirvire use in their delicious dishes to the bespoke, locally designed items in the boutique and the Skinny Laminx accents in our suite. Our room was utterly comfortable and the decor more than adequate, with the panoramas elevating it to “out of this world” status.

Floor-to-ceiling sliding doors reveal breathtaking lagoon and mountain views, with all the requisite creature comforts (fireplace, electric blankets, a decanter of port and gin, and a turn-down with a hand-written note on the pillow) making us feel very well-cared for.

Breakfast and dinner are served daily in a beautiful dining area, where two couches beside the fireplace beckon for post-prandial sessions. The food is generous and delicious – chefs Adrian and Gift have a knack for umami! Guests can also opt to have lunch at the lodge.

Suite features

David Rogers
  • king-sized bed (can be made into twins)
  • private deck with mountain views
  • en-suite bathroom with a free-standing bath
  • private outdoor shower
  • indoor sitting area
  • communal heated plunge pool
  • private hot tub at the Forest View Suite

Above and beyond: The wonderful service


David Rogers

The spellbinding setting aside, what made both our stays truly memorable was the service: warm, genuine and professional. From the moment we arrived, when Richard Chabarwa greeted us with heated lemongrass-scented hand towels and homemade iced tea, to Maria Murawa’s gently attentive service in the dining room, and chef Gift’s patience with our son during their pizza-making session, to the moment we said good-bye, we felt very special and well-cared-for throughout.

Onsite attractions

An abundance of activities awaits at this private paradise. Whether you feel like chilling at the lagoon-facing pool with a book, having a rejuvenating spa treatment, or would prefer to explore the natural surrounds, there’s something for everyone.

  • quad-biking
  • mountain-biking
  • boutique with bespoke clothing and accessories
  • spa
  • beach excursions
  • bird-watching
  • boat cruises
  • SUPing
  • kayaking
  • guided nature walks and birding

And, with all that’s on offer, the point of Mosaic Lagoon Lodge is to slow down, do less and savour more. I mean, where on earth can you fling open the doors of your rondavel, walk 20 steps, and be face to face with a flock of flamingo tip-toeing around the sunset-tinged lagoon? At Mosaic Lagoon Lodge, that’s where.

Distance from CT 2 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Mosaic Lagoon Lodge, Wortelgat Road, Stanford, Western Cape

title.rendered: Mooibaai B&B: A Tranquil Sojourn in Hout Bay

content.rendered:
In one of his musings, Nick Carroway, The Great Gatsby’s narrator writes: “I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.” Prohibition-era introspection aside, “within and without” is exactly how I’d describe Mooibaai: you’re less than five minutes from the hub of Hout Bay, and yet the little gravel road that takes you to this hideaway makes you feel like you’ve travelled far out of town.

Owned by Valerie Simons, a former banker from Belgium, Mooibaai is a passion project that took flight in early 2017 and has since become a favourite spot for international and local travellers alike. Perfect for those looking to stay close to the Cape Town scene without being in it, these guest cottages are an ideal choice for a holiday in the Mother City.

The setting

Mooibaai was originally a farm and is one of the few remaining properties in Hout Bay that has retained its Cape Dutch style. Surrounded by trees and planted with local fauna, the property feels entirely secluded. Enhancing its natural feel, Mooibaai’s backyard neighbour is World of Birds (although you can only hear them, not see them) and the large pool has fantastic mountain views.

The lodgings

Extremely spacious and minimalist in style, the five rooms at Mooibaai sleep two people each (with two slightly bigger rooms to accommodate children). Apart from the extremely comfortable bed, the bathrooms are a highlight: exquisitely decorated with pops of blue and green, they all have large walk-in showers and the Elephant suite has a huge bath.

Room features

  • five double rooms (Hippo, Ostrich, Penguin, Elephant and Rhino)
  • king-size bed
  • en-suite bathroom with spacious walk-in shower
  • private terrace with direct access to the pool deck
  • tea-and coffee-making facilities
  • complimentary wifi
  • fully equipped (communal) kitchen in the main house
  • communal lounge area with a TV in the main house (there is no DStv, but the wifi is good for streaming)

Finishing touches


Lana Lou Style

Enjoy a delicious continental-style breakfast served in the sunny courtyard, or inside on colder days. The homely breakfast features freshly baked bread and homemade jams (the persimmon jam is worth a trip to Hout Bay in itself) served with a variety of cheeses, cold meats, juices and coffee from the local Hout Bay Coffee Roastery.

If my stay had been longer, the Provençal-style courtyard, with its avocado-green chairs positioned under the lemon trees, is where I would imagine spending an entire afternoon, sipping coffee and rereading F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic.

Distance from CT 20 minutes
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Mooibaai Cottages, Horseshoe Farm, Stirrup Lane, Hout Bay

title.rendered: Perivoli Lagoon House: An Eco Villa Among Fynbos Near Hermanus

content.rendered:
There are few destinations that truly leave one lost for words, and this private oasis, set among the pristine natural beauty of a wilderness reserve near Hermanus, is one of them.

Perched on the edge of the breathtaking Klein River Lagoon outside Stanford, where the peaceful sounds of birdlife and majestic flamingos soaring across the water set the scene, Perivoli Lagoon House is a hidden haven just over two hour’s drive from Cape Town. With 140 hectares of untouched fynbos surrounding you and 180-degree views of the Klein River Mountains beyond, you can’t help but allow the stress of daily life to dissolve.

Hands-on hosts Marcelino and Simoné Henckert welcome guests to the ultra-contemporary villa, which was designed by local architect Gregg Goddard and decorated by Simoné herself, taking inspiration from the isolated wilderness surrounding it.

The perfect marriage between modern design and an undying appreciation for nature, the house blends seamlessly into its landscape (evident in the elegantly curved roof that mimics the Klein River Mountains and the movement of water on the lagoon).

Lay of the lagoon

The villa’s capacious interiors are dressed in warm shades of blue and brown that echo the landscape. The living area flows onto a sprawling wooden deck, where a heated infinity pool – overlooking the lagoon beyond – beckons for languid afternoons spent lounging in the sun.

Available to book on an exclusive-use basis only, the luxury home sleeps eight guests in four individually furnished bedrooms – ensuring an intimate, private and relaxing stay for family or friends.

Villa features

  • four double suites each featuring their own terrace with lagoon or mountain views
  • en-suite bathrooms with a bath and shower and complimentary Wild Olive products
  • eco-friendly fireplaces in each bedroom and living areas
  • indoor and outdoor living areas with deep sofas and shaded views of the lagoon
  • open plan state-of-the art kitchen with a dining area
  • separate scullery and laundry room
  • large wooden deck with a braai area and outdoor dining table
  • heated infinity pool and sun loungers
  • small herb garden providing fresh ingredients for the kitchen
  • private chef on request

Perivoli Lagoon House may be booked on an all-inclusive basis, but is also available for self-catering. The space is ideal for entertaining, with a fully kitted-out designer kitchen.

Should you feel like hanging up your apron for the evening, a private three-course dining experience curated by well-known local chef Madré, and paired with local wines from the area.

Tailored activities

In an area so vast, there’s naturally loads to do. Nature lovers will be in their element during the guided fynbos walks with an opportunity to encounter the abundant flora and fauna, while the beach excursion to the nearby Walker Bay Nature Reserve – where guests are treated to G&T sundowners on the sand dunes – is an unforgettable highlight.

Canoes, mountain bikes and even a speedboat are available for intrepid explorers, and the unique lagoonside location lends itself to a plethora of water sports such as water skiing, tubing and fishing.

Those looking to relax and reboot can request an in-house massage or yoga session (baskets with a mat are provided). And foodies and oenophiles will be in their element with a slew of culinary gems, wine estates, craft breweries and cheeseries in the nearby towns of Stanford and Hermanus.

Whether you stay for a weekend or a week, Perivoli Lagoon House is one of those otherworldly destinations that will fill you with a sense of awe you won’t soon forget.
Good to know Perivoli Lagoon House is owned by the Perivoli Trust, a philanthropically focused organisation that channels all profits to conserving and restoring the land, with any surplus being donated to the charitable Perivoli Schools Trust.
Distance from CT 2.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No

title.rendered: Wolfkop Camping Villages: Host Your Own Party in The Cederberg

content.rendered:
Hidden in the foothills of the Cederberg, overlooking the Olifants River in Citrusdal, Wolfkop Camping Villages is one of the country’s most popular camping and festival venues, offering an array of accommodation types – from camping to glamping. Flanked by mountains, the venue’s wide-open spaces provide the perfect spot for all types of gatherings, such as Wolfkop Weekender’s legendary Lilo River Flow and Power Flower Picnic.

We were thrilled to hear that the entire venue is now available for private hire… for those who’ve always dreamed of creating their own party utopia. Not only will you have the final say about the guestlist, music and catering, you’ll also be able to choose your own theme and decor. The Wolfkop organisers will allocate you to one of the five camping villages (Grootfontein, Biesievlak, Noordhoek, Middelpos and Golden Valley Deluxe Village) or the recently launched Glamping Villa.

Pick your party

If you’re looking to create a private-festival vibe, with its own theme; or you’re after an out-of-the-way spot to host a flamingo-themed bachelorette party; uninterrupted boys’ weekend or a milestone birthday with family and friends, there is no limit to your imagination and what you can create at this versatile venue. You could even host a team-building event here, or a yoga retreat… the options are endless.

No mess, no fuss

The Wolfkop team will handle setup – allocating a designated site to your party crew, complete with pre-pitched tents and braai areas with tables, chairs and cooking equipment, saving you the trouble.

All that’s left for you to do are the finer details: music, decor, food and the guests of your choice.

While you’re there…

The campsite has private four-poster jetties where campers can board canoes and meander down the river. There is also an abundance of scenic hiking trails in the area – the perfect base for exploring the mountains and farmland in the heart of the Cederberg.

If you’re looking to create an unforgettable experience that friends and family will be talking about for years to come, make Wolfkop your destination!

Good to know The cost includes cutlery, crockery, chairs, bean bags and four-poster jetties. Stage and sound cost extra.

title.rendered: Doringbos: A Private Escape in The Heart of The Cederberg

content.rendered:
Characterised by spectacularly beautiful rock formations and seemingly endless stretches of fynbos-dotted plains, the Cederberg conservancy casts a sacred spell over anyone who traverses it.

And here, in the midst of this hallowed landscape, perched cliffside on a privately owned farm above the flowing Doring River, this magnificent villa takes centre stage.


Situated on 3 000 hectares of private farmland, this holiday home (comprising a main farmhouse and four stone cottages) opened doors to guests in 2020 and offers all the sought-after services and facilities you could possibly fathom for an uninterrupted and exclusive stay in nature.


Accommodating 16 guests in total (four in the farmhouse, and between two and six people in each of the four cottages), Doringbos is a delightful mix of classic farm style and contemporary comfort.

Villa features

  • two en-suite bedrooms in the main house
  • two en-suite cottages with one bedroom each
  • two en-suite cottages with three bedrooms each
  • one en-suite semi-enclosed outdoor bedroom
  • fully equipped kitchen (main house)
  • two living rooms (main house)
  • formal dining room (main house)
  • large terrace for outdoor living and dining
  • breakfast boma
  • two swimming pools with views
  • wood-burning hot tub
  • complimentary wifi

All you need and more

With two rim-flow pools overlooking the arid valley, a wood-burning hot tub, full-time housekeeping staff, in-house spa treatments on request and a farm manager on hand, the house is a haven for hedonists.

The spacious kitchen is at your disposal should you wish to prepare your own meals. Guests seeking a complete break from domestic duties have the option of requesting a chef and sous chef to whip up all your meals (at an additional cost).

Those looking to get out and explore the area can do so, with quad-biking, horse-riding, mountain biking and kayaking along the Doring River (included in your stay). Fly-fishing lessons, picnics on horseback and helicopter transfers are available on request.

The 10-year-old home blends seamlessly with its natural environment, carrying with it an undying sense of charm and character, where attention to detail, breathtaking surrounds and heavenly highlights set the scene for an unforgettable escape.

Distance from CT 3.5 hours
Good to know The house is available to rent on an exclusive-use basis only, for a minimum of two nights.
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? Yes
Where to find it Doringbos Farm, Cederberg, Western Cape

title.rendered: Sanbona Explorer Camp: A Luxury Tented Safari Experience

content.rendered:
Just over a three-hour drive from Cape Town along the scenic Route 62 lies Sanbona Wildlife Reserve – a 58 000-hectare sanctuary of untouched landscape that’s home to the Big Five.

Tucked beneath the majestic Warmwaterberg Mountains in the heart of the Little Karoo, the malaria-free wildlife reserve is the Western Cape’s answer to an exclusive wilderness experience.

In addition to three lodges, the reserve hosts a series of Explorer Camp weekends during summer (October until April), where you can experience the great outdoors in the comfort of a luxury tent.

Bushveld luxury

Ideal for nature lovers seeking a true camping experience (minus the slog), Explorer Camp is entirely off the grid, and features three double tents with comfortable beds draped in mosquito nets, an eco shower and toilet facilities. It hosts a maximum of six people (16 years and older), and is available on an exclusive-use basis only.

All meals, house drinks and snacks are included, with a real highlight being starlit dinners – traditional South African dishes cooked over a campfire and enjoyed in the open-air lounge and dining area.

A walk to remember

Your stay includes two guided walking safaris, where you’ll get up close and personal with the striking Klein Karoo landscape. Hosted by a qualified, armed guide, you’re guaranteed a safe, fun and informative experience, learning about the unique and abundant birdlife, wildlife, vegetation, natural history and culture, for which the area is well-known.

Although the distances covered each day may vary, a trail can last for up to four hours. A game-viewing vehicle is also available at each camp, ready to drive you to another area of the reserve should you wish to explore a different section.

Once back from your walk, you’ll have time to relax and freshen up before enjoying a leisurely dinner under the stars. And then it’s time to hit the sack, exhausted from a day well spent in the African bush.

Good to know The Explorer Camp is available from 1 October 2020 – 30 April 2021.
Distance from CT 3.5 hours
Child friendly? Yes, from 16 years
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Route 62, between Montagu and Barrydale

title.rendered: Morukuru Beach Lodge: An Intimate Five-Star Hotel By The Sea

content.rendered:
It was late afternoon when we finally arrived at Morukuru – after an arduous, traffic-logged drive escalated by a puncture in Bredasdorp. A sea of smiling faces, warm hand shakes and refreshing rose-water cocktails welcomed us as we alighted from our vehicle, lifting our spirits instantly.

Preempting our plight (mending a puncture over a weekend in time for our journey home!), Riehan Groenwewald, one of our hosts, said: “Don’t worry; we’ll plug up your tyre here.” And then Mari Bosman, the hotel’s admin manager, added: “At Morukuru, we can do anything” – words that would come to exemplify our entire stay at this out-of-this-world sanctuary.

Gourmet canapés on the beach at sunset?
No problem.

With G&Ts three ways and fun-sized sand-boarding?
With pleasure.

Whales on demand?
That’s what you’re here for.

Mending punctures.
All in a day’s work.

Welcome to Morukuru Beach Lodge, a stylish eco lodge in what could be the most stunning setting in the world. Here are 10 reasons why we love it – and why it should feature on every nature lover and discerning traveller’s bucket list.

The setting

The five-roomed hotel lies on a sliver of prime seaside real estate characterised by towering white sand dunes, limestone cliffs, striking fynbos – and a stretch of Indian Ocean that becomes a daily playground for dozens of southern right whales every year between August and November.

Eco design

Inspired by its isolated seaside setting, Dutch owners Anke and Ed Zeeman wanted their lodge to reflect, complement and, most importantly, respect its surrounds, while maximising the stunning whale-watching opportunities, and encompassing the relaxed indoor-outdoor lifestyle.

Which is exactly what architect Nicholas Plewman did. Morukuru exquisitely delivers all the trappings of a the luxe life while keeping its footprint feather-light. Due to its remote location, the hotel is fully off the grid: electricity is generated by solar panels (with a backup generator for cloudy days); hot water is produced by pellet burners and the entire lodge has water-based underfloor heating.

Whales (and wildlife)

De Hoop offers the best land-based whale-watching in the world. Fact. But, there’s more to this seaside sanctuary than marine mammals. The neighbouring 36 000-hectare De Hoop Nature Reserve is home to the biggest herd of eland in the world, Cape mountain zebra, bontebok, ostriches, and over 260 species of birds, including the rare Cape Vulture. We spotted two endangered oystercatchers during a morning walk to the rockpools.

Turbo-chic rooms

The five immense and beautiful rooms (four face the ocean, and one boasts mesmerising dune vistas) were designed by Dutch interior designer Janine Butter, who has used nature’s tranquilising palette as her inspiration to create chic, modern, serene spaces that complement the landscape. Floor-to-ceiling sliding doors open onto a narrow balcony, revealing a 51-kilometre stretch of beach and the ocean beyond. A sea-facing daybed, cosy fireplace and lounge area make it hard to leave your room. Our three-year-old son was very taken with the hidden TV that pops up – 007 style – at the flick of a switch.

The limestone-clad bathrooms are beautifully designed, with touch-sensitive taps and an oversized shower head that makes bathtimes bliss…

And there are two communal tea-and-coffee nooks decked with everything you need to enjoy the perfect cuppa: rusks, biscuits, and a cosy dune-facing nook with a well-stocked bookshelf and comfy chairs.

Relaxed routine

After easing into the day with a bowl of granola, pain au chocolat or a tasty omelette, there’s the option of joining Riehan (or one of the other guides) for a marine walk, relaxed dune stroll, or an excursion to the nature reserve. There’s no pressure to go along, but the guides are fonts of information, so it’s well worth it.

If you’d prefer to explore on your own, the lodge has a fleet of bikes available.

Wining and dining

The food offering is superb – which is by no means a given in this remote neck of the woods. Highlights include the lamb cutlets that we enjoyed on the first night, the deconstructed bobotie for lunch, and the beef ravioli.

The people

The lodge opened in June 2018, and already the team beams with infectious enthusiasm. From Vusi, Romeo and Admire in the dining room to Elliot who took care of our every whim, and Nicholas who lit our fire every night, to the ever-helpful Lawrence, it feels as if every member of the staff is committed to making your stay memorable.

There’s so much to do

From swimming, snorkelling and sand-boarding to fynbos hikes, marine walks, bike rides and picnics on the beach, there’s loads to keep you relaxed (and busy). And, of course, there’s a pooldeck, complete with a Jacuzzi – the only place to be on chilly evenings…

The seclusion

There are very few places on earth that are untouched and untainted by commercialism. De Hoop is one of those rare, hidden gems. With the tranquilising ocean ahead, the salty sea air and fynbos-dotted sand dunes all around, you can’t not be enveloped by nature’s overriding sense of calm.

All the extras

The attention to the finer things is ultimately what makes a getaway stand out. At Morukuru, it’s all in the details. Some of our highlights were:

The outdoor hot-water tub waiting for us after our blustery marine walk
The rice milk in the fridge (as an alternative to dairy)
The complimentary use of all outdoor equipment (snorkels, masks, water shoes, wetsuits, mountain bikes, sand boards, ponchos, gumboots, beach umbrella, towels)
The hot-water bottles at turndown

It’s for all these reasons we’d return to Morukuru in a heartbeat.

An unmissable special

Morukuru Beach Lodge is currently running an incredible Last-Minute Special: from R5 000 per person per night (almost 50% off) for a minimum stay of two nights. Valid for stays until 17 December 2021, these rates are valid for last-minute bookings only (six weeks before arrival). Children under 2 years stay for free; children under 16 years sharing with two adults in the Ocean View Family Suite pay R 1 750 per night.

The special From R5 000 per person per night for a minimum stay of two nights
From R1 750 (children 3 –16 years)
Free (children 0 – 2 years)
Good to know The Honeymoon Suite is available for R5 500 per person
Please note The special does not include alcohol.

title.rendered: Cherry Glamping in Elgin: An Enchanted Forest Escape For Families + Friends

content.rendered:
Under rustling pine and blue gum trees in a private forest, with panoramic views of the towering Groenlandberg Mountains, this secluded forest hideaway in the heart of the Elgin Valley offers a unique camping experience where guests reside in fully decked-out luxury bell tents.

Located on the scenic Groenrug Estate, a mere hour’s drive from Cape Town, the private forest sleeps 18 to 100 guests across two different campsites (and one mobile offering), making it the ideal spot for a group of friends or extended family to enjoy an escape in nature; a company bosberaad, wedding, birthday celebration or mountain-biking retreat.

Evoking enchanted scenes from olden-day European fairy tales, the scattering of tents on the forest floor lights up at night, evoking the feeling of being lost among the enchanted forest glades. But, don’t take our word for it – you’ll need to experience it yourself to fully understand the magic!

The lodgings

The fully furnished, permanently pitched bell tents (and additional equipped bell tents) offer guests a comfortable space to rest their heads, and are spread across the Bloemkombos and Dennebos campsites, with the option of adding 25 additional tents for larger functions at either site.

Bloekombos Camp

At the bottom of the farm overlooking a sparkling dam and grasslands, Bloekombos Camp offers various outdoor areas, perfect for smaller festivals or larger functions. It also boasts uninterrupted views of resident springbok, bontebok and zebra as they wander down to the dam for a drink.

  • 21 fully equipped bell tents, sleeping two each
  • each tent features comfortable twin beds, cotton linen, towels, extra blankets, luggage rack, bed-end table, bedside tables with lamps, chairs and coat hooks
  • four shared bathrooms
  • large glass venue seating up to 180 people
  • large grass-surrounded dam
  • two fully equipped kitchens with a stove, fridges, freezer, cutlery, crockery and glassware
  • braai facilities

Dennebos Camp

At the very top of the farm, Dennebos Camp offers some of the best views in the valley, with many beautiful sundowner areas and easy access to Paul Cluver Wines and Lebanon MTB routes. It’s ideally suited to smaller functions of between 12 to 80 people.

  • 12 fully equipped bell tents, sleeping two each
  • each tent features comfortable twin beds, cotton linen, towels, extra blankets, luggage rack, bed-end table, bedside tables with lamps, chairs and coat hooks
  • three shared bathrooms
  • large covered deck and lapa seating up to 80 people
  • communal lounge with a 24-seater table and cosy fireplace
  • two natural swimming pools
  • sundowner area to relax and take in the beautiful view
  • large lawn for additional tents or lawn games
  • fully equipped kitchen with a stove, fridges, freezer, cutlery, crockery and glassware
  • braai facilities
  • outdoor chapel overlooking the mountains

Good to know In order to give guests exclusive use of all facilities, Cherry Glamping only accepts group bookings. The minimum booking over weekends is 12 tents, and five tents during the week.

Events and activities

With various open areas and the option of hiring it as an exclusive-use venue, Cherry Glamping is ideal for weddings, long-table lunches, open-field festivals and functions, or team-building weekends.

Here to chill? Enjoy relaxing by one of the pools. Adventure lovers will enjoy the slew of activities nearby: ziplining in Grabouw, horse-riding at Klein Paradys Equestrian Centre and Nature Discovery Tours. Wine-lovers will enjoy exploring the superb estates of the Elgin Wine Valley, while The Overberg and Whale Route make for a wonderful day trip. What’s more, various farm stalls and restaurants, including Gabriëlskloof Restaurant, Peregrine Farm Stall and The Hickory Shack, are a short drive away.

Whether you’re after a celebratory gathering, team-building venue, or a feet-up-and-chill break with close friends and family, this unique experience ticks all the boxes.

Distance from CT 1 hour
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Groenrug Estate, N2, Elgin, Western Cape

title.rendered: Mont Angelis: Secluded Mountain Cottages in Stellenbosch

content.rendered:
Dusty mountain roads, rambling vineyards, horse paddocks and the towering Stellenbosch Mountain make up the breathtaking Blaauwklippen Valley – a tranquil oasis just outside the Winelands town of Stellenbosch, and home to this charming cottage retreat.


Teagan Cunniffe

On an out-of-the-way wine farm, among rows of vines, the farm’s original dwellings have been transformed into nine self-catering cottages, each named after a famous angel, with a tasteful seraph-themed thread running through each one.

Away from the hustle of the Stellenbosch town centre, yet still close enough for exploration, Mont Angelis offers discerning travellers the type of space and quiet that can only be found in the countryside, making it ideal for a romantic getaway or weekend break with family and friends.

The lodgings


Teagan Cunniffe

Each well-designed and carefully appointed cottage boasts a private patio with breathtaking views of the imposing Stellenbosch Mountain. A wood-burning fireplace in each suite keeps things toasty in winter, while a sparkling pool in the central courtyard offers a reprieve from the heat during summer days in the valley.

Adonay Cottage

  • king-size extra-length bed
  • en-suite bathroom with a walk-in shower
  • private terrace with vineyard and mountain views
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • lounge area
  • wood-burning indoor fireplace
  • air-conditioning
  • complimentary wifi
  • international plug sockets
  • safe

While you’re there…

There are some wonderful mountain-biking and hiking trails on the farm’s doorstep, and a plethora of gastronomic and cultural hotspots in the centre of Stellenbosch, just a short 15-minute drive away.

Oenophiles will be in seventh heaven with Waterford, Dornier and Blaauwklippen Vineyards a hop, skip and a jump away.

Spacious, contemporary dwellings, breathtaking surrounds, and a laidback atmosphere make this a wonderful place for a secluded sojourn.

title.rendered: Wolfkop Camping Villas: A Riverside Escape in The Cederberg

content.rendered:
Hidden in the foothills of the Cederberg mountains, on the banks of the Olifants River, Wolfkop Camping Villages is one of the Cape’s well-known getaways, offering an array of accommodation options with river and mountain views to match.

Their recently added “villas” are conveniently perched on the banks of a gently flowing river.

The lodgings

Each tent sleeps up to six people, and has direct access to the river below.

Villa features

  • one master bedroom (featuring a luxurious king-size bed)
  • two additional dome tents with raised beds sleeping four
  • electric blankets
  • open-plan dining and living area with pallet couches and bean bags
  • kitchen with large dining table and chairs
  • large braai drum
  • wood-burning pizza oven
  • large central firepit

While you’re there…

There is a plethora of scenic hiking and horse-riding trails in the area – the perfect base for exploring the mountains and farmlands in the heart of the Cederberg. Feeling energetic? Hop in a kayak and meander down the river, or take your rod and do a spot of fishing.

After months of being locked down, few things are more restorative than an immersive stay in nature.

Distance from CT 2 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No

title.rendered: Sunshine Villa: A Sea-Facing Escape In Kalk Bay

content.rendered:
The seaside suburb of Kalk Bay grabbed international headlines in July 2018 when it was named one of The 12 Coolest Neighbourhoods Around The World by Forbes magazine. After taking a stroll along its vibey main road, and down to the harbour where fishing boats bob on the water, you’ll understand why.

Part-sleepy fishing village and part-artsy neighbourhood, Kalk Bay is a delicious mix of historic buildings, cobbled streets, bohemian bric-a-brac shops, vintage bookstores, art and antique galleries, quaint cafés and restaurants, colourful fishing vessels, offering a unique experience unlike anywhere else in Cape Town.

With all this on offer, it’s a wonderful spot to spend a weekend with family or friends, which we did recently during a stay at Sunshine Villa, a fantastically affordable villa on the mountainside in Kalk Bay. It’s conveniently located a few blocks up from the seafront, allowing us to make like locals and immerse ourselves in the beauty and charm of the surrounds.

We’d amble down to Kalk Bay’s main drag for a coffee each morning before hitting Dalebrook Tidal Pool to explore rock pools and watch plucky swimmers doing their early-morning laps. And then head back to our home-from-home for a braai and to watch the harbour activity from the sunny deck.

The lodgings

Sleeping four people in two bedrooms, Sunshine Villa is fully equipped with everything you need for an uninterrupted stay by the sea. Stellar location aside, its cost – from R500 per person per night – is perhaps its biggest drawcard.

Villa features

  • two bedrooms with queen-size beds
  • two en-suite bathrooms with shower and bath
  • spacious living room with fireplace
  • fully equipped kitchen with an open-plan dining area
  • Large deck with swimming pool and ocean views
  • Braai patio with a with-seater dining table
  • daily servicing during stay

While you’re there

Should you wish to leave the villa, Kalk Bay’s cultural scene is within walking distance. Dalebrook Tidal Pool is the perfect place for a refreshing dip and for kids to explore the tidal pools, while a slew of nearby boat trips and kayaking tours are a great way to immerse yourself in nature.

Distance from CT 30 minutes
Child friendly? Yes, but with adult supervision as the pool is uncovered and the garden wall that overlooks the street is accessible.
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it Sunshine Villa, 27a Gatesville Road, Kalk Bay, Cape Town

Please note Sunshine Villa is not taking bookings until further notice.

title.rendered: Glamping Along The Garden Route in AfriCamps Boutique Tents

content.rendered:
The stretch of road that winds its way from Witsand in the Western Cape to Storms River in the Eastern Cape is known as the Garden Route, arguably one of the most beautiful drives in the world. Flanked by verdant forests, craggy gorges, sprawling nature reserves and plunging valleys – with lakes, white-sand beaches and dreamy lagoons dotted along the way – the 300-kilometre-long expanse is home to a slew of small towns, the most well-known of which are Wilderness, Plettenberg Bay, Knysna, Sedgefield, Oudtshoorn and George.

While there is no shortage of pricey hotels, resorts and villas all vying for holidaymakers’ attention (especially in the coastal resorts of Plettenberg Bay and Knysna), one of the most authentic and rewarding ways to experience the region’s peerless beauty is an immersive stay in nature.

Which is where AfriCamps comes in. These spacious, custom-designed boutique tents, located on a series of beautiful farms and estates throughout South Africa, are fully furnished, with everything you need for a blissful stay in nature: decked-out kitchens, comfortable bedrooms, braai decks (with ridiculous views) and large showers. Indoor fireplace and electric blankets? Check!

Of the 11 AfriCamps in South Africa, there are four along the Garden Route, which we test-drove on a six-day glamping trip to the area that included a night at AfriCamps Kam’Bati (Swellendam), a night at AfriCamps Klein Karoo (Oudtshoorn), two nights at AfriCamps Oakhurst (Wilderness) and two nights at AfriCamps Ingwe (Plettenberg Bay).

It was a holiday that will be etched in our five-year-old son’s heart and mind forever. The endless array of adventures and activities on each of the farms we stayed at – from mountain-biking along dusty farm roads to canoeing, swimming in the farm dam, hot-tubbing at night, swinging from the tallest trees and feeding farm animals – had him rapt from dawn till dusk. The stuff that lifetime memories are made of…

AfriCamps at Kam’Bati, Swellendam

This family-friendly farm epitomises idyllic country life, where swimming, canoeing and fishing in the Breede River, playing mini-golf or doing a scavenger hunt will keep children entertained for hours, while adults catch up with friends around the fire.
The boutique tents are situated in a patch of forest, where you’ll be lulled to sleep by the sound of a gurgling river, and awake to the sight of ducks ambling down to the shore. Swellendam is a short drive away, and the Breede River offers intrepid explorers a trip into nature.
Distance from CT 2.5 hours
The lodgings

  • five boutique tents, each with a fully equipped kitchen (stove and microwave) and en-suite bathroom
  • each tent has two extra-length queen-size beds and a single bunk bed (sleeps five)
  • each tent has a spacious deck with outdoor seating and a built-in braai area
  • private outdoor wood-fired hot tub next to each tent
  • air conditioning and electric blankets

Things to do

  • three swimming pools with water slides
  • putt-putt course
  • pool lounge
  • jungle gym
  • canoe on the Breede River
  • vegetable garden
  • guided farm tour
  • fishing
  • hiking trails
  • wine farms in the Overberg
  • De Hoop Nature Reserve
  • Cape Agulhas
  • explore the nearby town of Swellendam

Good to know Breakfast and braai baskets are available at an additional charge.
There is also an on-site shop (open daily) and a bar (only on weekends once restrictions allow).
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Cost From R1 340 per night for two adults (depending on season)
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

AfriCamps Klein Karoo, Oudtshoorn

Separated from the Great Karoo by the Swartberg Mountain Range, the Klein Karoo is a semidesert landscape bathed in blissful solitude. Surrounded by spekboom trees and aloes, the tents here are positioned around a dam on a working ostrich farm, offering an accessible gateway into this fascinating world.
Distance from CT 5 hours
The lodgings

  • 12 water-facing boutique glamping tents
  • each tent has two extra-length queen-size beds and a single bunk bed (sleeps five), fully equipped kitchen and en-suite bathroom
  • private deck with outside seating and braai area, air conditioning, electric blankets and an indoor wood-burning fireplace

Things to do

  • guided stargazing
  • meerkat encounter
  • tour of the working ostrich farm
  • Karoo drive
  • Cango Caves
  • numerous restaurants, including Buffelsdrift Game Lodge restaurant, Nostalgie Restaurant and Karoo Pot

Good to know Breakfast and dinner baskets can be delivered to your tent at an additional cost.
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Cost From R1 190 per night for two adults (depending on season)
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

AfriCamps at Oakhurst, Wilderness

After the turnoff from Hoekwil, you’ll arrive at Oakhurst Farm where a treed dirt road takes you all the way to the spectacular glamping area. What travel brochures don’t mention is the All Saints Church – a magnificent Cape Dutch-style building hidden among the trees along the way – fit for a wedding! Divinity aside, this is an adventure lover’s paradise, with farm walks, a pump track (where chickens and pigs have right of way!), archery, a farm dam, a waterfall, and much more. Oh, you must order a Shelly’s chicken pie from the onsite farm shop – utterly delicious.
Distance from CT 5 hours
The lodgings

  • eight boutique tents each with a fully equipped kitchen (stove and oven) and en-suite bathroom
  • each tent has two extra-length queen-size beds and a single bunk bed (sleeps five)
  • each tent has a spacious deck with outdoor seating and a braai area
  • air conditioning, electric blankets and a wood-burning indoor fireplace
  • private wood-fired hot tub

Things to do

  • fishing and canoeing on the dam
  • mountain-biking
  • guided horse-riding
  • archery
  • hiking trail to the nearby waterfall
  • pump track
  • farm pool
  • massage treatments in the comfort of your own tent
  • Oakhurst Dairy to watch cows being milked and calves being fed
  • nearby beaches
  • hang gliding
  • paragliding
  • Wilderness Lakes Art Route
  • nearby craft markets

Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Cost From R1 340 per night for two adults (depending on season)
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

AfriCamps at Ingwe, Plettenberg Bay

The Crags, 20 kilometres from Plettenberg Bay, is peak Garden Route: lush forests, whooshing waterfalls and gorges where rivers flow through the mountains. It’s also an animal lover’s paradise. During our stay, we were greeted each morning by a herd of regal impala, who would saunter around our backyard browsing and grazing.
The elevated tents at this AfriCamps site offer spectacular views of the Tsitsikamma Mountain Range and surrounding valleys. It’s the perfect base for exploring Plettenberg Bay, Knysna and the Tsitsikamma National Park.
Don’t feel like venturing out? Do the 2.5km Couch Potato hike around the reserve.
Distance from CT 6 hours
The lodgings

  • six boutique glamping tents with a private deck, fully equipped kitchen (stove and microwave) and en-suite bathroom
  • each tent has two extra-length queen-size beds and a single bunk bed (sleeps five)
  • each tent has a large deck with outdoor seating and a pit braai
  • air conditioning and electric blankets
  • three tents feature their own outdoor wood-fired hot tub

Things to do

  • swimming pool
  • Couch Potato walking trail
  • farm dams
  • Monkeyland
  • Birds of Eden
  • Jukani Wildlife Centre
  • Hog Hollow Horse Trails

Good to know Breakfast baskets and traditional South African braai baskets can be delivered to your tent at an additional cost.
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Cost Boutique Tent: From R1 190 per night for two adults (depending on season)
Boutique Hot Tub Tent: From R1 490 per night for two adults (depending on season)
CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

title.rendered: KolKol Fynbos Pods: A Secluded Stay In A Mountain Cabin

content.rendered:
Just over an hour’s drive from Cape Town, sweeping views of the Babylonstoren Mountains and the impossibly peaceful sounds of nature set the scene for this secluded getaway.

Run by passionate owners Rudi and Karen Oosthuyse, KolKol Mountain Lodge is a luxurious retreat that appeals discerning (nature-loving) travellers seeking rest and relaxation in stunning surrounds.

In addition to nine existing cabins, the three recently introduced Fynbos Pods hidden in the mountains absolutely steal the show. Designed and built by Rudi himself, the picture-perfect pods are not merely a magnificent feat of structural engineering, but also a breathtaking place to rest your head in sumptuous comfort.

Pod perfection

A perfect marriage of natural materials and futuristic design, the wood-clad rectangular cocoons hover off the ground and blend seamlessly with their habitat. Inside, a neutral colour scheme echoes nature’s palette, with effortless open-plan living spaces maximising the beauty beyond.

Boasting 180-degree panoramas of rolling hills and towering mountains, the private deck has a braai area on one side and an outdoor lounge (complete with an outdoor shower and wooden shutters) on the other. Fresh mountain air, unadulterated tranquillity, the delicious whiff of braai smoke and a wood-fired hot tub waiting to be sunken into… what more could you ask for?

The lodgings

Each of the three pods – Pecan, Witwater and Firelilly – sleep two guests, and feature everything you need for a picture-perfect (self-catering) stay in nature.

  • one en-suite bedroom with a bath and shower
  • fully equipped kitchen
  • wood-fired pizza oven
  • open-plan living area with a two-way fireplace
  • wood-fired hot tub
  • outdoor shower
  • stone braai
  • outdoor lounge
  • Marshall Bluetooth speaker

Good to know Each pod is equipped with salt, pepper, braai salt, coffee, sugar, English and Rooibos tea, a small block of butter, rusks, 1litre milk, 1.5 litre bottle of still water and six free-range eggs.

While you’re there…

This scenic spot is the perfect place to do absolutely nothing, but if you’re looking to explore the area, there’s a three-kilometre hiking trail, nearby swimming dam and a mountain-biking trail. The Kogelberg Nature Reserve is a short drive away, as are the nearby towns of Hermanus and Stanford.

Looking for the ultimate escape? No one’s going to interrupt you up here…

Distance from CT 1.5 hours
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it KolKol Mountain Lodge, Van der Stel pass (via N2), Western Cape

CHECK AVAILABILITY + BOOK DIRECT

title.rendered: Cape Beach Villa Noordhoek: The Ultimate Seaside Escape

content.rendered:
It’s not often that a property is better in real life than it appears in photographs! Cape Beach Villa on Noordhoek’s Long Beach is one such spot. Flaunting unbelievable 180-degree panoramas of the most beautiful strip of beach in the world, this bright and airy, five-bedroom holiday house is as homely as it is hi-tech.

A walk-in fridge, Bluetooth connectivity with surround sound and an electric pool cover are just some of the slick features that make stays here effortless, while oversized daybeds, textured flokati rugs and good linen provide the type of cosseting that makes you feel cosy and cared for.

Spanning 700 square metres, there’s not a bad corner in the house. All the open-plan living areas (there are several, dotted around the villa, including an indoor braai space and a film room upstairs) have inordinately beautiful views – no matter what time of year you visit – and are dressed in a seductive mix of modern Scandi-style furniture and warm African art and accessories.

The lodgings

The view and proximity to the sea are undoubtedly the villa’s drawcards, which is not to say the rest of the house is unimpressive, boasting five en-suite bedrooms that sleep a maximum of 16 guests. We visited on one of those glorious sunny weekends in mid-winter, and spent our days on the deck, sipping G&Ts, watching the surfers from our loungers, braaing and breathing in the fresh sea air, while our five-year-old son flopped in and out of the swimming pool. The stuff that seaside fantasies are made of…

Villa features

  • five en-suite bedrooms (with heating and cooling functionality), pure cotton linen, hairdryers and thoughtfully selected bathroom amenities
  • one of the bedrooms has four single bunk beds and sleeps up to six people
  • a separate cottage (with one bedroom and two single sofa beds)
  • fully equipped kitchen with state-of-the-art appliances and a walk-in fridge
  • indoor braai and butlers kitchen
  • spacious open-plan dining area
  • seaview lounge overlooking the pool and ocean
  • cosy fireside reading lounge
  • television lounge with a floating TV
  • complimentary wifi throughout the house
  • Carribean-inspired sunset bar
  • wraparound wooden deck
  • private access to beach
  • outdoor shower
  • solar-heated swimming pool and sun loungers

About the owners

The husband-and-wife owners, French-born Christine Dercourt and Brit Andrew Simmonds, bought the home in 2019 with the intention of spending European winters (South African summers) here – like swallows. “Andrew’s sister lives in Franschhoek and after visiting her many times, we fell in love with the country and knew we wanted to semi-retire here,” recalls Christine.

They settled on Noordhoek for its proximity to nature, and also because it ticks both of their passions. “We had a shock when we visited the house,” she remembers. “The views on that pristine beach… eight kilometres of empty space… it is simply unique. There is no other house like this in the world. This view is rare and so precious.” This, from a couple who has travelled extensively. “Also, there are so many things to do here. We are both nature lovers and fell in love with the raw beauty of the region. Andrew is very sporty and I enjoy the cultural side of things. Noordhoek has it all.”

“Every morning, we go down to the beach barefoot and enjoy a long walk before breakfast. And every evening, we celebrate the beauty of the view from the Sunset Bar. This is pure luxury!”

Distance from CT 30 minutes
Child friendly? Yes, for children over 10
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it 5 Ratelklip Close, Chapmans Peak, Cape Town

title.rendered: The Aven: Rent This Private Ibiza-Style Villa in Camps Bay

content.rendered:
If you’re looking for a convenient yet spectacular weekend getaway, there’s no shortage of superb rentals right on our doorstep. One such spot is The Aven – a beautiful private villa on the scenic Rontree Avenue in Camps Bay.

The Ibiza-esque property oozes a luxe holiday charm, with polished concrete floors and minimalist off-white, cream and wood-textured interiors. Panoramic views of the Atlantic Ocean and Lion’s Head imbue the communal areas with a sense of calm that is carried through to each of the eight bedrooms.

The best part? You can have it all to yourself…

The lodgings

The Aven has eight luxurious en-suite rooms, dressed in a minimalisticstyle, with warm colours providing a decidedly Mediterranean feel for a dream vacation in Cape Town.

  • fully stocked mini-bar
  • tea and coffee station
  • air-conditioning
  • complimentary wi-fi
  • smart TV
  • terrace with a garden or ocean view
  • breakfast daily
  • room service daily
  • swimming pool with views of the Atlantic Ocean
  • private garden
  • secure parking
  • 24-hour security

Above and beyond

Aside from a slew of amenities and attractions, the property is safe and secure, and has stringent hygiene protocols in place, including full sanitation, deep-cleaning of each room upon arrival, regular Covid-19 tests and daily temperature checks for staff (who wear gloves and masks at all times), and private à la carte breakfasts served to your room.

Are you ready for la vida Ibiza?

Distance from CT 10 min
Child friendly? No children under 12 without prior arrangement
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it 12 Rontree Avenue, Camps Bay, Cape Town

MAKE A RESERVATION

title.rendered: Stanford Valley Country Lodge: Cosy Self-Catering Cottages

content.rendered:
Surrounded by treed hills and lush meadows where horses graze and springbokkies roam, this idyllic farm in the Klein River Valley spans 480 hectares of unadulterated natural beauty, and is home to a small collection of white-washed farm cottages. Meandering mountain paths, fynbos-dotted plains, horse paddocks and a farm dam are just some of the features that make it the perfect country escape for nature-loving couples, friends and families.

In addition to the natural beauty and tranquil surrounds, the estate’s hands-on owners Reinder and Elsabe Nauta are among the most charming we’ve met. Their warm and generous hospitality has trickled down to the rest of the team, notably host Sarah Dix and Rodgers Chiredzero, who went out of his way to make sure we had everything we needed for the duration of our stay.

Most of the cottages are self-catering, but the onsite Manor House Restaurant serves excellent country cooking where breakfast, lunch and dinner are available at an additional cost. The perfect option should you tire of braaing on your private stoep…

The lodgings

There are 15 cottages spread across the vast property – namely Sagewood, Fynbos and Erica (each two-sleepers); Stables and Pincushion-Bluebell (each sleeping four); and Protea and Milkwood (each five-sleepers). Every cottage has been lovingly furnished with pared-down rustic charm – and all have breathtaking views of the mountains or meadows.

  • comfortable bedrooms with en-suite bathrooms
  • private patios with mountain or meadow views
  • five of the cottages have fully equipped kitchenettes and braai facilities
  • four of the self-catering units have two bedrooms and private gardens
  • tea- and coffee-making facilities (and home-baked rusks)
  • mini fridge
  • wood-fired fireplace (unlimited firewood supplied)
  • outdoor seating area

Country cuisine

Breakfast, lunch and dinner are served at the acclaimed on-site Manor House Restaurant (rated in Gourmet Guide’s 2019 Top 75 restaurants in SA) – where head chef Janine van der Nest and her team create modern-country dishes.

The curated menu changes regularly, according to season and availability of produce but this winter, guests can expect the likes of waterblommetjie risotto, smoked snoek samoosas and boerpampoen pasta pillows to start, followed by crispy cauliflower dumplings, braised lamb and slow-roasted Cluver and Jack pork belly for mains, with naartjie marmalade malva; dark chocolate fondant and hibiscus pear with cinnamon pavlova and whipped cream for dessert.

A sumptuous special

Enquire about their flexible-use voucher and enjoy a stay for less in a private country cottage, overlooking a lemon tree and lavender bush, with a fireplace and braai wood delivered daily. Valid until 8 December 2020.

Exercise enthusiasts will enjoy mountain-biking or hiking in the newly built mountain trails, or taking a bracing plunge in the spring-fed farm dam. All this and more awaits just under a two-hour drive from Cape Town.

Distance from CT 2 hours
Child friendly? Yes
Pet friendly? No
Where to find it R326, Stanford, Western Cape
